MINUTE ORDER (paperless), upon consideration of plaintiff's 30 Motion to Clarify Temporary Restraining Order, which appropriately raises promptly a difference of interpretation of the Court's 21 Injunction Order for clarification to ensure full compliance with the obligations imposed, ISSUING the following ORDER regarding defendants' obligations under the Court's 21 Injunction Order expressly directing (1) defendants to "communicate to every recipient of a request for disclosure of any relationship with Perkins Coie LLP or any person associated with the firm..." that "such request is rescinded," id. at 2 (emphasis supplied), regardless of which agency subject to Executive Order 14230 made the request, and (2) four of the named defendants, namely, U.S. Department of Justice; U.S. Attorney General Pamela Bondi; the Office of Management and Budget ("OMB"); and OMB Director Russell Vought, to "immediately issue guidance to all other agencies subject to Executive Order 14230 to suspend and rescind any implementation or enforcement" of the enjoined portions of the Executive Order, id. (emphasis supplied):(1) DIRECTING defendants U.S. Department of Justice; Pamela Bondi, in her official capacity as U.S. Attorney General; the Office of Management and Budget; and Russell Vought, in his official capacity as Director of the Office of Management and Budget, to immediately issue guidance to all other agencies subject to Executive Order 14230 directing them immediately to (a) communicate to every recipient of a request for disclosure of any relationship with Perkins Coie LLP or any person associated with the firm, made pursuant to Section 3(a) of Executive Order 14230, that such request is rescinded until further order of this Court; and (b) cease making such requests for disclosure, pursuant to Section 3(a) of Executive Order 14230, until further order of the Court; and(2) FURTHER DIRECTING defendants to file, by 12:00 PM on March 20, 2025, a status report describing the steps taken to ensure compliance with this Order and certifying compliance with its requirements, in light of the fact that "some agencies have requested that contractors respond to disclosure requests as soon as Thursday, March 20, 2025." case_data.summary:
This case challenged President Trump's executive order targeting a powerhouse law firm for its historic association with progressive causes and clients.

On March 11, 2025, Perkins Coie LLP, an international law firm based out of Seattle, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. Plaintiff named the United States of America, the U.S. Department of Justice, the Federal Communications Commission, the Office of Management and Budget, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, the Office of Personnel Management, the General Services Administration, the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, and their corresponding agency heads as defendants.

Attorneys at Perkins Coie represented Hillary Clinton's 2016 presidential campaign, defended Joe Biden's victory in the 2020 election against several legal challenges, and litigated numerous voting rights cases. In this lawsuit, Perkins Coie challenged EO 14230, "Addressing Risks from Perkins Coie LLP," issued on March 6, 2025. The EO accused the law firm of being "dishonest and dangerous" in its legal representation and of engaging in unlawful discrimination through its Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion initiatives, and it sought to immediately suspend all security clearances, government benefits and services, and contracts previously granted by the federal government to Perkins Coie LLP or its employees. Plaintiff Perkins Cole alleged that the EO constituted the unauthorized exercise of judicial power by the executive branch and violated the Due Process Clause, the Equal Protection Clause, the First Amendment, the Sixth Amendment, and the Fifth Amendment.

On Count I, plaintiff alleged that sanctioning a private law firm through the EO constituted an ultra vires Presidential action, as there was no authority in the Constitution for the President to take such action. On Counts II and III, plaintiff alleged that the EO constituted an unconstitutional deprivation of procedural due process. Plaintiff alleged that the EO was given without any notice and was unconstitutionally vague, as it provided no basis to understand what conduct was prohibited, nor any guidance on which interactions and buildings were banned from plaintiff's employees, nor what constituted a "diversity, equity, and inclusion" policy. On Count IV, plaintiff alleged that the EO was an unconstitutional denial of equal protection because its purpose was to discriminate against plaintiff specifically. On Count V, plaintiff alleged that the EO amounted to political viewpoint discrimination in violation of First Amendment free speech and associational rights. On Count VI, plaintiff alleged that the EO's requirement that government contractors to disclose any business they do with plaintiff amounted to compelled disclosure under in violation of First Amendment free speech and associational rights. On Count VII, plaintiff alleged that the EO was retaliation for plaintiff's statements in favor of diversity and inclusion in violation of First Amendment free speech and associational rights. On Count VIII, plaintiff alleged that the EO violated plaintiff's clients’ Sixth Amendment rights to counsel because it directed agency heads to limit government employees from engaging with the Plaintiff's employees and thus impaired plaintiff’s ability to advance clients’ interests before the government. Finally, on Count IX, plaintiff alleged that defendants violated the Fifth Amendment right to counsel because the EO interfered with and chilled client-lawyer relationships.

Represented by the private law firm Williams & Connolly, plaintiff sought declaratory and injunctive relief enjoining the implementation of the Order. Plaintiff filed a motion for temporary restraining order the same day.

The case was assigned to Judge Beryl Howell; after a hearing on March 12, the court granted plaintiff's requested temporary restraining order, enjoining the government from implementing the parts of the EO relating to federal contracting, hiring, and access to government buildings. The TRO was extended into a preliminary injunction on March 14.

On March 21, 2025, Defendants filed a motion to disqualify Judge Howell. Defendants argued that Judge Howell was "insufficiently impartial" due to her involvement in the Mueller Report and the investigation of Special Counsel John Durham, two cases where she issued orders against President Trump. Defendants argued that Judge Howell's previous record constituted a "pattern of hostility" against defendants. 

Finding that defendants' motion relied only on “speculation[ and] innuendo” in seeking to get another Judge assigned to the case, Judge Howell denied the motion to disqualify on March 26. 

On April 2, plaintiff filed a motion for summary judgment and permanent injunction. Plaintiff requested that the court declare that Executive Order 14230 was unlawful and that the court permanently enjoin defendants from implementing or enforcing the EO in any way. 

The same day, defendants filed a motion to dismiss. Defendants asserted that the President possessed broad authority to regulate executive functions and that the courts should not interfere with these. Defendants further argued that Plaintiff lacked standing to sue, asserting that the firm had not demonstrated a concrete injury directly attributable to the executive order. Finally, defendants contended that the claims presented by plaintiff were not justiciable, as they involved political questions beyond the purview of judicial review. Defendants also filed a motion for reconsideration regarding the March 12 temporary restraining order. 

Many amicus briefs were filed in support of plaintiff by public interest groups, former members of government, private citizens, law firms, and nonprofits. Amici also included the former Presidents of the District of Columbia Bar; 363 legal professors at various U.S. law schools; and a collection of nonprofits including the ACLU, Cato Institute, Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, and the Institute for Justice.

On April 23, 2025, President Trump posted on Truth Social about the case, saying he was "suing the law firm of Perkins Coie for their egregious and unlawful acts." Trump also took aim at Judge Howell, calling her a "highly biased and unfair disaster" and an "unmitigated train wreck" and expressed confidence that he had a "100% perfect case."

On May 2, the court denied defendants' motion to dismiss and granted summary judgment for Perkins Coie, holding that EO 14230 violated the firm's clients' Fifth and Sixth Amendment rights to counsel, unfairly infringed on the firm's First Amendment right to petition the government, and was impermissibly vague in violation of the Fifth Amendment Due Process clause because it “fail[ed] to provide adequate notice as to what are prohibited ‘diversity, equity, and inclusion’ policies.”

The court granted a permanent injunction prohibiting the government from implementing or enforcing Executive Order 14230, and requiring them to undo all implementation that had already occurred. It retained jurisidiction over the matter to enforce that injunction.

Following defendants' motion to clarify the court's order, on May 20, 2025, the court confirmed that its permanent injunction only applied to plaintiff Perkins Coie and did not enjoin defendants with respect to other law firms or the legal profession generally.

On June 30, 2025, defendants appealed to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. This case remains ongoing.

BRENDAN CARR, RUSSELL T. VOUGHT, 
ANDREA R. LUCAS, CHARLES EZELL, 
STEPHEN EHEKIAN, and TULSI GABBARD, 
 
Defendants. 
 
 
 
COMPLAINT 
 
Plaintiff, the law firm of Perkins Coie LLP, brings this case against the U.S. Department 
of Justice, the Federal Communications Commission, the Office of Management & Budget, the 
Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, the Office of Personnel Management, the General 
Services Administration, the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, the United States of 
America, and, in their respective official capacities, Pamela J. Bondi, Brendan Carr, Russell T. 
Vought, Andrea R. Lucas, Charles Ezell, Stephen Ehekian, and Tulsi Gabbard, and states as 
follows: 
   
1 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 1     Filed 03/11/25     Page 2 of 43
 
WHAT THIS CASE IS ABOUT 
1.  This  case  concerns  an  Executive  Order  issued  on  March  6,  2025,  entitled, 
โAddressing Risks From Perkins Coie LLPโ (โthe Orderโ).  The Order is an affront to the 
Constitution and our adversarial system of justice.  Its plain purpose is to bully those who advocate 
points of view that the President perceives as adverse to the views of his Administration, whether 
those views are presented on behalf of paying or pro bono clients.  Perkins Coie brings this case 
reluctantly.    The  firm  is  comprised  of lawyers  who  advocate  for  clients;  its  attorneys  and 
employees are not activists or partisans.  But Perkins Coieโs ability to represent the interests of its 
clientsโand its ability to operate as a legal-services business at allโare under direct and imminent 
threat.  Perkins Coie cannot allow its clients to be bullied.  The firm is committed to a resolute 
defense of the rule of law, without regard to party or ideology, and therefore brings this lawsuit to 
declare the Order unlawful and to enjoin its implementation. 
2.  The Orderโs peculiar title betrays its oddity as an Executive Order, for its purpose 
is not executive in nature.  Rather, the Order reflects a purpose that is judicialโto adjudicate 
whether a handful of lawyers at Perkins Coie LLP (โPerkins Coie,โ โthe law firm,โ or โthe firmโ) 
engaged in misconduct in the course of litigation and then to punish them by:  (1) terminating 
government contracts with firm clients, thereby driving away current and prospective clients; (2) 
denying all members and employees of the firm access to federal buildings and meetings or other 
engagement with federal employees; and (3) immediately suspending, and possibly revoking, 
security clearances for all firm employees. 
3.  The Order imposes these punishments on the entire law firm even though the 
attorneys involved in the purported misconduct numbered a mere handful of the more than 1,200 
2 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 1     Filed 03/11/25     Page 3 of 43

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 1     Filed 03/11/25     Page 33 of 43
 
119.  The  Equal  Protection  Clause  bars  the  government  from  disfavoring similarly 
situated individuals without a constitutionally legitimate basis.  Vill. of Willowbrook v. Olech, 528 
U.S. 562, 564 (2000).   
120.  To justify discriminatory conduct, the government must put forward a โplausible 
reasonโ for its differential treatment, FCC v. Beach Communications, Inc., 508 U.S. 307, 313-14 
(1993), which cannot be โso attenuatedโ from its conduct โas to render [it] arbitrary or irrational.โ  
City of Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc., 473 U.S. 432, 446 (1985) (citing, inter alia, 
United States Department of Agriculture v. Moreno, 413 U.S. 528, 535 (1973)).  โ[A] bare desire 
to harm a politically unpopular groupโ is โnot [a] legitimate state interest[].โ  City of Cleburne, 
473 U.S. at 447.   
121.  The purpose of the Order is to discriminate against Perkins Coie.  The Order 
intentionally targets Perkins Coie with extraordinary sanctions not levied on other, materially 
similarly situated firms or lawyers.   
122.  The improper motive behind the Order is also apparent on its face and through the 
Presidentโs related public statements, as well as the statements of members of his Administration.   
123.  The government lacks even a rational justification for the Order.  Among other 
things, the Order targets a 1,200-lawyer, 21-office international law firm based on almost ten-year-
old allegations that courts have rejected and that involve partners whom Perkins Coie has not 
employed for several years.  The Order expressly seeks to punish Perkins Coie for representing 
clients in lawsuits that successfully struck down unconstitutional election laws and defeated 
challenges brought by President Trump or his allies to the results of the 2020 election.  There is 
not a shred of evidence of any national security threat from Perkins Coie, let alone one sufficient 
33 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 1     Filed 03/11/25     Page 34 of 43
 
to justify barring Perkins Coie from engaging in government contracts, interacting with federal 
employees, and accessing federal buildings.   
124.  The Order is therefore in violation of the Equal Protection Clause.  
125.  The Orderโs violations cause ongoing and irreparable harm to Perkins Coie. 
COUNT V 
(Against All Defendants) 
Unconstitutional Denial of First Amendment 
Free Speech and Associational Rights (Political Viewpoint Discrimination) 
126.  Plaintiff repeats and realleges the allegations set forth in each of the preceding 
paragraphs as if fully set forth herein. 
127.  The First Amendment prohibits the regulation or censure of speech based on โโthe 
specific motivating ideology or the opinion or perspective of the speaker.โโ  Reed v. Town of 
Gilbert, 576 U.S. 155, 168-69 (2015) (quoting Rosenberger v. Rector and Visitors of Univ. of Va., 
515 U.S. 819, 829 (1995)).  Such government action is a โโblatantโ and โegregious form of content 
discriminationโโ and is subject to strict scrutiny.  Reed, 576 U.S. at 168, 171. 
128.  The  Order  (and  Fact  Sheet  explaining  it)  constitute  viewpoint  discrimination 
because they single out and punish Perkins Coie for its association with, and advocacy on behalf 
of, the Presidentโs political opponents in the 2016 and 2020 elections. 
129.  The Order and Fact Sheet do not distinguish between the clientโs viewpoint and the 
firmโs zealous advocacy of that viewpoint, but attribute the viewpoint to the firm and retaliate 
against the firm on that basis. 
130.  The Orderโs viewpoint discrimination is all the more egregious because it concerns 
speech that is at the core of First Amendment protectionโi.e., speech concerning the election of 
candidates to national office and what the law should be governing those elections. 
34 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 1     Filed 03/11/25     Page 35 of 43
 
131.  Viewpoint discrimination that is retaliatory cannot be justified by any government 
interest.  Even if the Order were not retaliatory in purpose and in the publicโs perception, as it 
clearly is, no compelling interest can support the Order.  It is the job of the courts to police 
misconduct by the lawyers who appear before them, and it is the job of state bars to discipline 
ethical misconduct by members of the bar.  The President has no authority in these areas.  Here, 
moreover, the President has presented his claims concerning the 2016 election to a federal court, 
and that court has dismissed his case.  He presented his claims regarding the 2020 election to 
numerous courts without material success, frequently losing to parties represented by Perkins Coie.  
Nor can there be any compelling government interest in punishing the entire Perkins Coie firm of 
over 1,200 lawyers and over 1,200 non-lawyer professionals now, in 2025, when the purportedly 
offending speech (i) occurred years ago and (ii) involved a mere handful of lawyers (iii) none of 
whom are members or employees of the firm today. 
132.  The First Amendment forbids the governmentโs use of a patronage system whereby 
it  conditions  government  benefits,  such  as  contracts,  access  to  government  facilities  or 
employment, or security clearances on political support or affiliation.  Even where there is no right 
to a government benefit, the government cannot revoke or condition benefits on grounds that 
violate the First Amendmentโs guarantee of free speech and association.  The Order punishes 
Perkins Coie for the lack of political fealty and conditions the further receipt of government 
benefits on adherence to the Presidentโs political points of view.   
133.  The First Amendment protects the right to petition the government for redress of 
grievances.  Such petition includes seeking relief in courts of law and agencies of government.  
The Order violates that right by denying the ability of Perkins Coie lawyers to enter public 
buildings and, even short of entry, communicate and meet with government employees (two of 
35 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 1     Filed 03/11/25     Page 36 of 43
 
whom have already refused to meet with Perkins Coie lawyers, as scheduled before issuance of 
the Order). 
134.  Facially  overbroad  regulation  violates  the  First  Amendment  because  it  chills 
protected speech.  The Order and Fact Sheet are facially overbroad, inter alia, because they do not 
define  what  constitutes  โdishonest  and  dangerous  activity.โ    The  Order,  on  its  face,  also 
encompasses  legally  protected  activity,  such  as  petitioning  the  government  for  redress  of 
grievances in the courts. 
135.  The Orderโs violations cause ongoing and irreparable harm to Perkins Coie. 
COUNT VI 
(Against All Defendants) 
Unconstitutional Denial of First Amendment 
Free Speech and Associational Rights (Compelled Disclosures) 
136.  Plaintiff repeats and realleges the allegations set forth in each of the preceding 
paragraphs as if fully set forth herein. 
137.  The First Amendment limits the governmentโs ability to compel individuals to 
disclose their โaffiliation[s] with groups engaged in advocacy.โ  NAACP v. Alabama ex rel. 
Patterson, 357 U.S. 449, 462 (1958).  Such compelled disclosures must satisfy โexacting scrutiny,โ 
a standard that requires the government to show that there is โa substantial relation between the 
disclosure  requirement  and  a  sufficiently  important  governmental  interest.โ    Americans  for 
Prosperity Found. v. Bonta, 594 U.S. 595, 607 (2021). 
138.  Section 3 of the Order โrequire[s] [g]overnment contractors to disclose any business 
they do with Perkins Coie and whether that business is related to the subject of the Government 
contract.โ 
36 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 1     Filed 03/11/25     Page 37 of 43
 
139.  Perkins Coie has third-party standing to assert the First Amendment rights of its 
clients who are subject to Section 3 because (i) Perkins Coieโs right to freedom of association is 
burdened by the disclosure requirements and the disclosure requirements will cause Perkins Coie 
to lose clients; (ii) Perkins Coie has a close relationship with its clients; and (iii) Perkins Coieโs 
clients are hindered from challenging the disclosure requirements and protecting their First 
Amendment rights because the act of challenging the disclosure requirements would require the 
clients to disclose their relationship with Perkins Coie.  See Ctr. for Democracy & Tech. v. Trump, 
507 F. Supp. 3d 213, 223โ24 (D.D.C. 2020). 
140.  The governmentโs interestโretaliating against Perkins Coie for First-Amendment-
protected activity of which the President disapprovesโis not โsufficiently importantโ to withstand 
exacting scrutiny.   
141.  Requiring all โ[g]overnment contractors to disclose any business they do with 
Perkins Coieโ irrespective of โwhether that business is related to the subject of the Government 
contract,โ EO ยง 3, is not the kind of โnarrow specificityโ required by the First Amendment, Natโl 
Assโn for Advancement of Colored People v. Button, 371 U.S. 415, 433 (1963).   
142.  Section 3 of the Order is facially unconstitutional. 
143.  This constitutional violation causes ongoing and irreparable harm to Perkins Coie. 
COUNT VII 
(Against All Defendants) 
Unconstitutional Denial of First Amendment Free Speech and Associational Rights 
(Retaliation for Statements in Favor of Diversity and Inclusion) 
 
144.  Plaintiff repeats and realleges the allegations set forth in each of the preceding 
paragraphs as if fully set forth herein. 
37 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 1     Filed 03/11/25     Page 38 of 43
 
145.  Perkins Coie has a longstanding commitment to diversity and inclusion and has 
made, and continues to make, public statements advancing the ideals of diversity, equity, and 
inclusion.  Such statements of political opinion are core protected speech. 
146.  The Orderโs viewpoint discrimination stems from the threatened investigation and 
enforcement action against Perkins Coie because it embraces programs and policies that are 
deemed by the Order to be discriminatory โdiversity, equity, and inclusionโ policies.   
147.  Section 1 of the Order falsely asserts that Perkins Coie, by espousing views 
supportive of diversity and inclusion, has โdisrespect[ed] . . .the bedrock principle of equalityโ and 
concludes that good cause therefore exists to terminate Perkins Coieโs national security clearances 
and access to any federal funds.  Such allegations are bad faith, pretextual, and lack any basis in 
fact. 
148.  The Orderโs threatened investigation and enforcement action by the EEOC and 
the Department of Justice against Perkins Coie because it embraces programs and policies that 
espouse a belief in โdiversity, equity, and inclusionโ makes it a violation of the firmโs First 
Amendment right of free expression. 
149.  The Orderโs threatened suspension of active security clearances held by Perkins 
Coie employees because the firm embraces programs and policies that espouse a belief in 
โdiversity, equity, and inclusionโ makes it a violation of the firmโs First Amendment right of free 
expression. 
150.  The Orderโs threatened termination of contracts or funding with Perkins Coie or 
entities doing business with Perkins Coie because the firm embraces programs and policies that 
espouse a belief in โdiversity, equity, and inclusionโ makes it a violation of the firmโs First 
Amendment right of free expression. 
38 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 1     Filed 03/11/25     Page 39 of 43
 
151.  Section 4(a) of the Order unconstitutionally retaliates against Perkins Coie for First 
Amendment protected speech supporting and promoting diversity, equity, and inclusion in the 
legal profession and orders the Chair of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission to 
investigate โrepresentative large, influential or industry leading law firmsโโlike Perkins Coieโ
to determine if discriminatory hiring and promotion practices exist.  
152.  Section 4(b) instructs the Attorney General, in coordination with the Chair of the 
Equal  Employment  Opportunity  Commission  and  the  State  Attorneys  General,  to  conduct 
compliance investigations of any โlarge law firmsโโlike Perkins Coieโwho do business with 
federal entities and to take โadditional actionsโ deemed appropriate by the Attorney General โin 
light of the evidence uncovered.โ   
153.  The threatened investigations into Perkin Coieโs hiring, retention, promotion, and 
training practices constitute a โretaliatory action sufficient to deter a person of ordinary firmness 
in [Perkins Coieโs] position from speaking againโ and would thus be cognizable.  Aref v. Lynch, 
833 F.3d 242, 258 (D.C. Cir. 2016).  See Smith v. Plati, 258 F.3d 1167, 1176 (10th Cir. 2001) 
(Retaliatory  actions  โthat  would  chill  a  person  of  ordinary  firmnessโ  include  โprosecution, 
threatened prosecution, bad faith investigation, and legal harassment.โ). 
154.  The threat of an investigation by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission 
and/or the Department of Justice imposes costs on Perkins Coie, including the potential costs of 
litigation and the need to redirect dedicated resources from other purposes to engage with the 
investigation.  Those harms are in addition to the reputational harms imposed on Perkins Coie by 
the false allegations in the Order which have resulted or will result in the loss of clients, employees, 
and prestige. 
155.  The Order, thus, violates the First Amendment. 
39 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 1     Filed 03/11/25     Page 40 of 43
 
156.  That violation causes ongoing and irreparable harm to Perkins Coie. 
COUNT VIII 
(Against All Defendants) 
Unconstitutional Denial of Right to Counsel (Sixth Amendment) 
157.  Plaintiff repeats and realleges the allegations set forth in each of the preceding 
paragraphs as if fully set forth herein. 
158.  The Sixth Amendment to the United States Constitution guarantees that โ[i]n all 
criminal prosecutions, the accused shall enjoy the right โฆ to have the Assistance of Counsel for 
his defence.โ  U.S. Const. amend. VI.  The Sixth Amendment affords criminal defendants the right 
to effective assistance provided by the counsel of oneโs choosing.  Strickland v. Washington, 466 
U.S. 668, 686 (1984); Wheat v. United States, 486 U.S. 153, 159 (1988).  Actions that substantially 
interfere with, or deprive, the right to counsel constitute a violation of the Sixth Amendment. 
159.  Lawyers have prudential, third-party standing to challenge violations of their 
clientsโ Sixth Amendment or Due Process rights to counsel that interfere with the lawyersโ 
practice.  Caplin & Drysdale, Chartered v. United States, 491 U.S. 617, 624 n.3 (1989); U.S. Depโt 
of Lab. v. Triplett, 494 U.S. 715, 720 (1990).  In particular, because an attorneyโs duty to provide 
effective counsel โmay not be fettered by harassment of government officials,โ a lawyer has 
โstanding to challenge any act which interferes with his professional obligation to his client and 
thereby, through the lawyer, invades the clientโs constitutional right to counsel.โ  Wounded Knee 
Legal Def. v. Fed. Bureau of Investigation, 507 F.2d 1281, 1284 (8th Cir. 1974).  Because the firm 
represents criminal defendants and others in dealings with the government, it has standing to 
challenge the Orderโs attempted interference with its clientsโ rights to counsel. 
40 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 1     Filed 03/11/25     Page 41 of 43
 
160.  The Order violates the firmโs clientsโ Sixth Amendment rights to counsel because 
it directs โthe heads of all agenciesโ without exception to โlimit[] Government employees acting 
in their official capacity from engaging with Perkins Coie employeesโ and thus significantly 
impairs Perkins Coieโs ability to advance clientsโ interests before the government. 
161.  The Order violates the firmโs clientsโ Sixth Amendment rights to counsel because 
it directs โthe heads of all agenciesโ without exception to โlimit[] official access from Federal 
Government buildings to employees of Perkins Coieโ and thus significantly impairs Perkins Coieโs 
ability to advance clientsโ interests before the government. 
162.  The  Order  also  violates  the  firmโs  clientsโ  Sixth  Amendment  rights  to  their 
preferred counsel because it โrequire[s] Government contractors to disclose any business they do 
with Perkins Coieโ and thus compels clients to choose between their livelihood and their preferred 
counsel. 
163.  The Order is therefore in violation of the Sixth Amendment. 
164.  This violation causes ongoing and irreparable harm to Perkins Coie. 
COUNT IX 
(Against All Defendants) 
Unconstitutional Denial of Right to Counsel (Fifth Amendment) 
165.  Plaintiff repeats and realleges the allegations set forth in each of the preceding 
paragraphs as if fully set forth herein. 
166.  Lawyers and clients have due process interests in their contractual and professional 
relationships.   
167.  The Orderโs sanctions interfere with and chill all of those representations and 
relationships.  Like the firmโs other due process interests, the Order failed to provide adequate 
41 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 1     Filed 03/11/25     Page 42 of 43
 
process before interfering with the firmโs and clientsโ due process rights to counsel.  And because 
these sanctionsโwhich punish a firm for successful lawsuits and threaten the firmโs clientsโare 
not rationally related to a legitimate government interest they cannot stand.   
168.  The Orderโs violations cause ongoing and irreparable harm to Perkins Coie and its 
clients. 
PRAYER FOR RELIEF 
  WHEREFORE, Perkins Coie respectfully requests that the Court: 
169.   Declare the Executive Order unconstitutional as violative of the Separation of 
Powers and Article II of and the First, Fifth and Sixth Amendments to the Constitution. 
170.  Immediately enjoin implementation of the Order pending consideration of a motion 
for preliminary injunction. 
171.  Preliminarily, then permanently, enjoin implementation of the Order. 
172.  Grant such other relief as the Court deems just and proper.

ORDER 
Upon consideration of plaintiff Perkins Coie LLPโs Motion for Summary Judgment and 
Declaratory and Permanent Injunctive Relief, ECF No. 182; the governmentโs Renewed Motion 
to Dismiss and for Expedited Judgment, ECF No. 183; the memoranda, declarations, and 
exhibits submitted in support and opposition; the arguments in support and opposition presented 
at the motions hearing held on April 23, 2025, and the entire record herein, it is hereby: 
(1)  ORDERED that plaintiffโs Motion for Summary Judgment and Declaratory and 
Permanent Injunctive Relief, ECF No. 182, is GRANTED; it is further 
(2)  ORDERED that the governmentโs Renewed Motion to Dismiss and for Expedited 
Judgment, ECF No. 183, is DENIED; it is further 
(3)  DECLARED that Executive Order 14230, 90 Fed. Reg. 11781 (Mar. 11, 2025), 
issued by the President on March 6, 2025, entitled โAddressing Risks from Perkins Coie LLP,โ is 
unlawful because it violates the First, Fifth, and Sixth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution and 
is therefore null and void; it is further 
(4)  ORDERED that: 
1 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 184     Filed 05/02/25     Page 2 of 5
A.   defendants are PERMANENTLY ENJOINED from implementing or enforcing 
Executive Order 14230 in any way; 
B.  defendants are PERMANENTLY ENJOINED from using or considering in any 
way or for any purpose the statements in Section 1 of Executive Order 14230, 
including but not limited to in any interactions with plaintiff or government 
contractors or with employees or other personnel of plaintiff or government 
contractors; 
C.  defendants are DIRECTED to rescind all formal or informal guidance or other 
direction provided to officers, staff, employees, or independent contractors of the 
federal government to communicate, effectuate, implement, or enforce Executive 
Order 14230, including Sections 2 and 4 that were not subject to this Courtโs 
Temporary Restraining Order, ECF No. 21; 
D.  defendants are DIRECTED immediately to notify all officers, staff, employees, and 
independent contractors subject to Executive Order 14230 that Executive Order 
14230 is unlawful, null and void in its entirety and therefore should be disregarded, 
including all prior formal or informal advice, opinions, or direction previously 
received or communicated to effectuate, implement, or enforce Executive Order 
14230, and that all departments, agencies, officers, staff, employees, and independent 
contractors of the federal government should carry on with their ordinary course of 
business, absent Executive Order 14230, with Perkins Coie LLP,1 its personnel, its 
clients and its clientsโ personnel known or believed by them to be associated with 
Perkins Coie LLP; 
 
1   Perkins Coie LLP includes its affiliates, predecessors, successors, assigns, directors, officers, partners, 
employees, and agents. 
2 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 184     Filed 05/02/25     Page 3 of 5
E.  defendants are DIRECTED to cease any security clearance review, made pursuant to 
Sections 1 or 2(a) of Executive Order 14230, and to reverse any suspension or 
revocation of any active security clearances, made pursuant to Sections 1 or 2(a) of 
Executive Order 14230, although nothing in this Order shall bar defendants from 
suspending or revoking any security clearances for reasons independent of Executive 
Order 14230, an association with Perkins Coie LLP, or the reasons set out in Section 
1 of Executive Order 14230; 
F.  defendants the Office of Management and Budget and Russell Vought, in his official 
capacity as director of the Office of Management and Budget, are DIRECTED to 
identify all government goods, property, material, and services, provided for the 
benefit of Perkins Coie LLP, that were previously identified pursuant to Section 2(b) 
of Executive Order 14230, and immediately to issue direction to the relevant heads of 
agencies that they are to reverse and rescind any cessation of the provision of such 
material or services, if such cessation was done pursuant to Executive Order 14230; 
G. defendants are DIRECTED immediately to (a) communicate to every recipient of a 
formal or informal request for disclosure of any relationship with Perkins Coie LLP 
or any person associated with the firm, made pursuant to Sections 2(b) or 3(a) of 
Executive Order 14230, that such request is permanently rescinded, the recipient need 
not respond to such request, and there shall be no consequences for not responding to 
such request; (b) cease making such requests for disclosure; and (c) segregate and 
disregard any responses received to such requests for disclosure; 
H. defendants U.S. Department of Justice; Pamela Bondi in her official capacity as U.S. 
Attorney General; Equal Employment Opportunity Commission; and Andrea R. 
3 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 184     Filed 05/02/25     Page 4 of 5
Lucas, in her official capacity as Acting Chair of the Equal Employment Opportunity 
Commission, are DIRECTED immediately to cease any investigation of Perkins 
Coie LLP made pursuant to Section 4 of Executive Order 14230, and to withdraw any 
requests for information from Perkins Coie LLP or other investigative steps made

I.  defendants are ORDERED that they must, in good faith, take such other steps as are 
necessary to prevent the implementation or enforcement of Executive Order 14230 
and to reverse any implementation or enforcement of Executive Order 14230 that has 
occurred or is occurring; 
J.  defendants U.S. Department of Justice; Pamela Bondi, in her official capacity as 
U.S. Attorney General; the Office of Management and Budget; and Russell Vought, 
in his official capacity as Director of the Office of Management and Budget, are 
DIRECTED additionally to: 
i.  provide a copy of this Order to all defendants, any other departments, 
agencies, and entities that received Executive Order 14230 or guidance related

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 34     Filed 03/21/25     Page 1 of 8
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA 
 
 
   
PERKINS COIE LLP,   
 
 
 
  Plaintiff, 
 
 
Civil Action No. 1:25-cv-00716-BAH 
v.  
 
 
U.S. DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE, et al., 
 
  Defendants. 
 
DEFENDANTSโ MOTION TO DISQUALIFY  
JUDGE BERYL HOWELL 
 
Fair proceedings free from any suggestion of impartiality are essential to the integrity of 
our countryโs judiciary and the need to curtail ongoing improper encroachments of President 
Trumpโs Executive Power playing out across the country.  In this case, reasonable observers may 
well view this Court as insufficiently impartial to adjudicate the meritless challenges to President 
Trumpโs efforts to implement the agenda that the American people elected him to carry out.  In 
fact, this Court has repeatedly demonstrated partiality against and animus towards the President.  
Examples include this Court enabling the improper efforts of disgraced former prosecutor Jack 
Smith despite a readily apparent lack of venue in this District; wrongly suggesting in public that 
President Trump is an authoritarian; and incorrectly finding that President Trumpโthe most well-
known man on Earthโpresents a flight risk where even the prior Administrationโs Department of 
Justice had to retract such a suggestion.  This Courtโs comments at the hearing on the meritless 
motion for a temporary restraining order (โTROโ) in this case, including gratuitous and biased 
references by this Court regarding the investigation of Special Counsel Robert Mueller (โMueller 
Reportโ), confirm that reasonable observers may view this Court as incapable of fairly adjudicating 
these claims against the Commander-In-Chief. 
1 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 34     Filed 03/21/25     Page 2 of 8
Accordingly, to ensure that these proceedings are free from any suggestion of impartiality, 
the Defendants move to disqualify this Court under 28 U.S.C. ยง 455(a).  This case involves serious 
concerns about election integrity, national security, and the past actions of the law firm Perkins 
Coie LLP.  Given the statements made by the Court at the initial hearing in this matter and its out-
of-court statements, the Courtโs impartiality in this case might reasonably be questioned.  See 28 
U.S.C.  ยง  455(a).   Accordingly,  Defendants  respectfully  submit  that  this  matter  should  be 
transferred to another district court judge who was neither involved with Mueller Report nor the 
investigation  of  Special  Counsel  John  Durham  (โDurham  Investigationโ)  and  who  has  not 
demonstrated a pattern of hostility towards Defendants. 
LEGAL STANDARD 
Recusal is mandatory where a judgeโs โimpartiality might reasonably be questioned.โ  28 
U.S.C. ยง 455(a) (explaining that a federal judge โshall disqualify himself in any proceeding in 
which his impartiality might reasonably be questionedโ).  A judge also โshallโ recuse where she 
โhas a personal bias or prejudice concerning a party.โ  28 U.S.C. ยง 455(b)(1).  โ[T]he question is 
whether a reasonable and informed observer would question the judgeโs impartiality.โ  Stone v. 
U.S. Embassy Tokyo, 2020 WL 5653699, at *1 (D.D.C. 2020) (quotation omitted); see also SEC v. 
Loving Spirit Found., 392 F.3d 486, 493 (D.C. Cir. 2004).  
The touchstone for recusal under Section 455(a) is โnot the reality of bias or prejudice but 
its appearance.โ  Liteky v. United States, 510 U.S. 540, 548 (1994). โThe very purpose of ยง 455(a) 
is to promote confidence in the judiciary by avoiding even the appearance of impropriety whenever 
possible.โ United States v. Patti, 337 F.3d 1317, 1321 (11th Cir. 2003) (quoting Liljeberg v. Health 
Servs. Acquisition Corp., 486 U.S. 847, 865 (1988)).  Thus, โany doubts must be resolved in favor 
of recusal.โ Id.; see also Parker v. Connors Steel Co., 855 F.2d 1510, 1524 (11th Cir. 1988) (โIt 
has been stated on numerous occasions that when a judge harbors any doubts concerning whether 
2 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 34     Filed 03/21/25     Page 3 of 8
his disqualification is required he should resolve the doubt in favor of disqualification.โ).  The 
Supreme Court has explained that remarks by a court may constitute a basis for recusal if โthey 
display a deep-seated favoritism or antagonism that would make fair judgment impossible.โ Liteky 
510 U.S. at 555. 
DISCUSSION 
Plaintiffโs lawsuit challenges the Presidentโs Executive Order issued on March 6, 2025, 
entitled Addressing Risks from Perkins Coie LLP (the โEOโ).  The EO explains that Perkins Coie 
LLP has engaged in a โpatternโ of โdishonest and dangerous activity.โ  Notably, members of 
Plaintiffโs firm were involved in matters subject to the Durham Investigation, culminating with the 
indictment of one member of Plaintiffโs firm.  This Court is no stranger to this issue given its role 
in the Mueller investigation.  
a.  This Courtโs Systematic Hostility Toward President Trump 
This Court has not kept its disdain for President Trump secret.  It has voiced its thoughts 
loudlyโboth inside and outside the courtroom.  In a November 2023 speech that this Court 
delivered at a Womenโs White Collar Defense Association event, it lamented that America is at a 
โcrossroadsโ and, in an apparent reference to President Trump, indicated that one path would lead 
to  authoritarianism.    See  2023  WWCDA  Awards  Gala  Full  Video, 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sNDnJWh1gzE  (last  accessed  March  21,  2025).    Judge 
Howellโs remarks did not live in a vacuum.  They prompted a judicial misconduct complaint from 
a member of Congress and serious media scrutiny.  See Complaint of Judicial Misconduct Against 
Judge  Beryl  Howell  filed  by  Elise  Stefanik, 
https://s3.documentcloud.org/documents/24224161/stefanik20judicial20complaint20howell20de
c2015.pdf  (Dec. 15, 2023); see, e.g., Gerstein, Judge key to Jan. 6 cases warns US faces 
3 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 34     Filed 03/21/25     Page 4 of 8
โauthoritarianโ  threat,  https://www.politico.com/news/2023/11/28/jan-6-authoritarian-threat-
democracy-00129013 (Nov. 28, 2023).  
This Courtโs hostility toward President Trump is also on full display through her disdain 
for his supporters.  For example, in response to a basic dismissal motion under Federal Criminal 
Rule of Procedure 48, this Court took the opportunity to grandstand about the 2020 election and 
President Trumpโs supporters.  Directly rejecting the presidentโs determination that dismissal of 
pending indictments โagainst individuals for their conduct related to the events at or near the 
United States Capitol on January 6, 2021โ would โend[] a grave national injustice that has been 
perpetrated upon the American people over the last four years and begin[] a process of national 
reconciliation,โ  Proclamation  10887,  Granting  Pardons  and  Commutation  of  Sentences  for 
Certain Offenses Relating to the Events at or Near the United States Capitol on January 6, 2021, 
90 Fed. Reg. 8331 (Jan. 20, 2025), the Court curtly stated that no โnational injusticeโ occurred 
here, United States v. Jovanovic, Case No. 25-cr-15, 2025 WL 266551, at *2 (D.D.C. Jan. 2025).  
The  Court  then  engaged  in  wholly  inappropriate  name-calling,  repeatedly  calling  President 
Trumpโs  supporters  โsore  losersโ  and  stating  that  the  Presidentโs  pronouncement  relayed  a 
โrevisionist myth.โ  Id.  
This Courtโs pattern of hostility toward President Trump is not limited to his supporters.  It 
also utilized the judicial power against President Trump himself.  During the height of Jack Smithโs 
weaponized lawfare against President Trump, this Court found โreason to believe that the former 
President  would  โflee  from  prosecutionโโโdespite  President Trump  being  one  of  the  most 
recognizable figures in the world.  See In re Sealed Case, 77 F.4th 815, 822 n.2 (D.C. Cir 2023) 
(noting that even the government later acknowledged that โit had โerrantly included flight from 
prosecution as a predicateโ in its applicationโ).   
4 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 34     Filed 03/21/25     Page 5 of 8
Later, in the waning moments of its seven-year term as Chief Judge, this Court ruled that 
private documents belonging to President Trumpโs personal attorney must be given to Smith.  
Invoking the rarely used โcrime-fraudโ exception, this Court pierced attorney-client privilege, 
ordering President Trumpโs attorney to testify before a D.C. grand jury investigating the alleged 
retention of government documents in South Florida.  See In re: Sealed Case, Case No. 1:23-gj-
00010 (D.D.C); Feuer, Trump Lawyer in Mar-a-Lago Case Must Hand Over Records, Appeals 
Court Says, NEW YORK TIMES (Mar. 22, 2023).  Notably, this Court issued its ruling when venue 
for the grand jury proceedings in the case was squarely in the Southern District of Floridaโnot 
the District of Columbia.  Indeed, the district court judge in the Southern District of Florida 
appeared troubled by this Courtโs procedure and seemed inclined to engage in an extended 
evidentiary hearing to address it before ultimately dismissing the unconstitutional case against 
President Trump on other grounds.  See, e.g., ECF Nos. 566, 605, United States v. Trump, No. 23-
cr-80101 (S.D. Fla. 2023). 
Additionally, in 2023, this Court held Twitter in contempt of court for failing to comply 
with Jack Smithโs demand for President Trumpโs Twitter direct messages.  This Court could not 
resist from editorializing, asking whether Musk โwants to cozy up with the former presidentโ and 
whether Twitterโs efforts were โto make Donald Trump feel like he is a particularly welcomed new 
renewed user of Twitter.โ  In the Matter of the Search of: Information That is Stored at Premises 
Controlled by Twitter Inc., Case. No. 1:23-sc-00031 (D.D.C.), Transcript of Hearing Before the 
Honorable Beryl Howell on February 7, 2023, at 1:32 p.m. at 36:5โ6, 60:18โ20.  
   
5 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 34     Filed 03/21/25     Page 6 of 8
b.  This Courtโs Conduct in this Case  
Simultaneously with filing its complaint in this case, Plaintiff filed a motion for a TRO.  
See ECF No. 2.  Within 24 hours of the complaint being filed, this Court conducted a a hearing on 
the TRO and ruled from the bench, granting the requested relief.  See ECF No. 21.  
During the course of the hearing, a number of exchanges took place between the Court and 
Defendantsโ counsel regarding the activities of Perkins Coie attorneys and the 2016 electionโ
specifically their involvement in the procurement and distribution of the report by Fusion GPS. 
ECF No. 22, Hearing Tr. at 31โ35, 49โ50. This report has now been fully discredited, and the role 
of Perkins Coie attorneys in the distribution of this report was a centerpiece of the Durham 
Investigation.  Yet this Court stated: โI know the President has justโyou know, based on reading 
these papers, he was upset about that in 2016; he was so upset about this still he filed a lawsuit 
against Perkins Coie and others in the Southern District of Florida that was dismissed in rapid 
order.  He keeps bringing it up.  Itโs like he doesnโt want any of us to forget Fusion GPS.  He doesnโt 
want any of us to forget thatโany of this.  He really has a bee in his bonnet about it.โ  ECF No. 
22, Hearing Tr. at 49:22โ50:5 (emphasis added).  
  As seen in the above exchange, issues of the Durham Investigation, the Fusion GPS report, 
and the Mueller Report are central to the EO.  The Courtโs condescending remark that President 
Trump had โa bee in his bonnetโ about Fusion GPS demonstrate a concerning and dismissive 
approach to the entire Durham Investigationโan Investigation that touched on the Courtโs role in 
the Mueller Report and one in which members of the Plaintiffโs firm played a primary and essential 
role.  The entire Fusion GPS fiasco is a lamentable part of this nationโs history.  As demonstrated 
through comments in this proceeding, other judicial proceedings, and in the public, observers 
6 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 34     Filed 03/21/25     Page 7 of 8
might reasonably have concerns about the Courtโs impartiality in this matter.  Recusal is warranted 
to ensure these proceedings fair and free from concerns about impartiality. 
CONCLUSION 
Defendants deserve a court proceeding free from concerns about impartiality.  In order to 
remove the possibility of any impartiality to these proceedings, Defendants respectfully request 
that this Court recuse itself and return this matter to assignment before a judge free from any 
appearance of hostility toward this Administration and is otherwise unconnected with any matter 
related to the Mueller Report or Durham Investigation.

documents.text:
Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 185     Filed 05/02/25     Page 1 of 102
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA 
 
PERKINS COIE LLP,   
   
Plaintiff,   
  Civil Action No. 25-716 (BAH) 
v.   
  Judge Beryl A. Howell 
U.S. DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE, et al., 
 
Defendants. 
 
MEMORANDUM OPINION  
No American President has ever before issued executive orders like the one at issue in this 
lawsuit targeting a prominent law firm with adverse actions to be executed by all Executive branch 
agencies but, in purpose and effect, this action draws from a playbook as old as Shakespeare, who 
penned the phrase: โThe first thing we do, letโs kill all the lawyers.โ  WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE, 
HENRY VI, PART 2, act 4, sc. 2, l. 75.  When Shakespeareโs character, a rebel leader intent on 
becoming king, see id. l. 74, hears this suggestion, he promptly incorporates this tactic as part of 
his plan to assume power, leading in the same scene to the rebel leader demanding โ[a]way with 
him,โ referring to an educated clerk, who โcan make obligations and write court hand,โ id. l. 90, 
106.  Eliminating lawyers as the guardians of the rule of law removes a major impediment to the 
path to more power.  See Walters v. Natโl Assโn of Radiation Survivors, 473 U.S. 305, 371 n.24 
(1985) (Stevens, J., dissenting) (explaining the import of the same Shakespearean statement to be 
โthat disposing of lawyers is a step in the direction of a totalitarian form of governmentโ).  
The importance of independent lawyers to ensuring the American judicial systemโs fair 
and impartial administration of justice has been recognized in this country since its founding era.  
In 1770, John Adams made the singularly unpopular decision to represent eight British soldiers 
charged with murder for their roles in the Boston Massacre and โclaimed later to have suffered the 
1 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 185     Filed 05/02/25     Page 2 of 102
loss of more than half his practice.โ  DAVID MCCULLOUGH, JOHN ADAMS 68 (2001).  โI had no 
hesitation,โ he explained, since โCouncil ought to be the very last thing that an accused Person 
should want in a free Country,โ and โthe Bar ought . . . to be independent and impartial at all Times 
And  in  every  Circumstance.โ    3  DIARY  AND  AUTOBIOGRAPHY  OF  JOHN  ADAMS  293  (L.H. 
Butterfield et al. eds., 1961).  When the Bill of Rights was ratified, these principles were codified 
into the Constitution: The Sixth Amendment secured the right, in โall criminal prosecutions,โ to 
โhave the  Assistance of Counsel for . . . defence,โ U.S. CONST. amend. VI, and the Fifth 
Amendment protected โthe right to the aid of counsel when desired and provided by the party 
asserting the right,โ Powell v. Alabama, 287 U.S. 45, 68 (1932).1  This value placed on the role of 
lawyers caught the attention of Alexis de Tocqueville, who in reflecting on his travels throughout 
the early United States in 1831 and 1832, insightfully remarked that โthe authority . . . intrusted to 
members of the legal profession . . . is the most powerful existing security against the excesses of 
democracy.โ  ALEXIS DE TOCQUEVILLE, DEMOCRACY IN AMERICA 301 (Henry Reeve trans., 2002) 
(1835).   
The Supreme Court, too, has recognized the importance of lawyers to the functioning of 
the American judicial system, since โ[a]n informed, independent judiciary presumes an informed, 
independent bar.โ  Legal Servs. Corp. v. Velazquez, 531 U.S. 533, 545 (2001).  This is so because 
Congress may legislate, the President may implement, and courts may adjudicate, โbut only the 
lawyers can prepare and submit the great issues of human justice under law in such manner and 
 
1   Amici law professors highlight that the right to counsel was included in the Bill of Rights in large part to 
avoid โexecutive control of access to counsel,โ which โcould distort the administration of justice.โ  Br. of Amici 
Curiae 363 Law Professors in Supp. of Pl.โs Mot. for Summ. J. & for Declaratory & Permanent Injunctive Relief 
(โLaw Professorsโ Br.โ) at 11, ECF No. 49; see also id. at 11-15 (reviewing the history of the inclusion of this right 
in the Bill of Rights and collecting authorities).  The historical backdrop for these provisions, as Justice Black 
explained, was in direct response to the โwillingness . . . of the courts of England to make โshort shriftโ of unpopular 
and uncooperative groups,โ including โlawyers whose greatest crime was to dare to defend unpopular causes.โ  
Cohen v. Hurley, 366 U.S. 117, 139-40 (1961) (Black, J., dissenting); see also id. at 138-41 (reviewing the history 
and protections adopted in response).    
2 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 185     Filed 05/02/25     Page 3 of 102
form that courts, in the ultimate, may be effective.โ  Williams v. Beto, 354 F.2d 698, 706 (5th Cir. 
1965).  Absent their crucial independence, lawyers would โbecome nothing more than parrots of 
the views of whatever group wields governmental power at the moment.โ  Cohen v. Hurley, 366 
U.S. 117, 138 (1961) (Black, J., dissenting). 
The instant case presents an unprecedented attack on these foundational principles.  On 
March 6, 2025, President Trump issued Executive Order 14230 (โEO 14230โ), 90 Fed. Reg. 11781 
(Mar. 11, 2025), entitled โAddressing Risks from Perkins Coie LLP.โ2  By its terms, this Order 
stigmatizes and penalizes a particular law firm and its employeesโfrom its partners to its associate 
attorneys, secretaries, and mailroom attendantsโdue to the Firmโs representation, both in the past 
and currently, of clients pursuing claims and taking positions with which the current President 
disagrees, as well as the Firmโs own speech.  In a cringe-worthy twist on the theatrical phrase 
โLetโs kill all the lawyers,โ EO 14230 takes the approach of โLetโs kill the lawyers I donโt like,โ 
sending the clear message: lawyers must stick to the party line, or else.3   
 
2   See Pl.โs Mot. for Summ. J. & Declaratory & Permanent Injunctive Relief (โPl.โs MSJโ), Ex. 4, Declaration 
of Christopher N. Manning, Partner, Williams & Connolly (โManning Decl.โ), Ex. 27 (โEO 14230โ), ECF No. 39-4 
at 127.   
 
3   This message has been heard and heeded by some targeted law firms, as reflected in their choice, after 
reportedly direct dealings with the current White House, to agree to demand terms, perhaps viewing this choice as 
the best alternative for their clients and employees.  Yet, some clients may harbor reservations about the 
implications of such deals for the vigorous and zealous representation to which they are entitled from ethically 
responsible counsel, since at least the publicized deal terms appear only to forestall, rather than eliminate, the threat 
of being targeted in an Executive Order.  As amici former and current general counsel caution, a โfundamental 
premise of the rule of lawโ is that โwhen parties challenge the government, their lawyers โoppose[] the designated 
representatives of the State,โ and โ[t]he system assumes that adversarial testing will ultimately advance the public 
interest in truth and fairness.โ  This safeguard against government overreach fails when attorneys cannot โadvanc[e] 
the undivided interests of [their] client[s]โ for fear of reprisal from the government.โ  Br. of Amici Curiae Former & 
Current General Counsel Supporting Pl. Perkins Coie, LLP at 9-10, ECF No. 99 (alterations in original; internal 
citation omitted) (quoting Polk County v. Dodson, 454 U.S. 312, 318-19 (1981)).

A.  Motion to Dismiss 
1.  Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(1) 
โโFederal courts are courts of limited jurisdiction,โ possessing โonly that power authorized 
by the Constitution and statute.โ  Gunn v. Minton, 568 U.S. 251, 256 (2013) (quoting Kokkonen v. 
Guardian Life Ins. Co., 511 U.S. 375, 377 (1994)).  Absent subject-matter jurisdiction over a case, 
the court must dismiss it.  See Arbaugh v. Y & H Corp., 546 U.S. 500, 506-07 (2006) (citing 
Kontrick v. Ryan, 540 U.S. 443, 455 (2004)); Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(h)(3). 
To survive a motion to dismiss under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(1), the plaintiff 
bears the burden of demonstrating the courtโs subject-matter jurisdiction over the claim at issue.

2.  Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 8 and 12(b)(6) 
Rule 8(a) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure requires that a complaint contain a short 
and plain statement of the grounds upon which the courtโs jurisdiction depends, a short and plain 
statement of the claim showing that the pleader is entitled to relief, and a demand for judgment for 
the relief the pleader seeks.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 8(a).  This rule โdoes not require detailed factual 
allegations,  but  it  demands  more  than  an  unadorned,  the-defendant-unlawfully-harmed-me 
accusation.โ  Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 556 U.S. 662, 678 (2009) (quotations omitted).  In addition, Rule 
8(d) states  that  โ[e]ach  allegation  must  be  simple,  concise,  and  direct.โ   Fed.  R.  Civ.  P. 
8(d)(1).  โTaken together, [those provisions] underscore the emphasis placed on clarity and brevity 
by the federal pleading rules,โ Ciralsky v. CIA, 355 F.3d 661, 669 (D.C. Cir. 2004) (cleaned up), 
and to โgive the defendants fair notice of what the claim is and the grounds upon which it 
rests,โ Jones  v.  Kirchner,  835  F.3d  74,  79  (D.C.  Cir.  2016).    The  purposes  of  Rule 
8(a)(2) and Rule 12(b)(6) overlap, but dismissal is proper under Rule 8 when the complaint is โso

To survive a Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss, the โcomplaint must contain sufficient

U.S. at 678 (quoting Bell Atl. Corp. v. Twombly, 550 U.S. 544, 570 (2007)).  A facially plausible 
claim pleads facts that are not โโmerely consistent withโ a defendantโs liabilityโ but โthat allow[] 
the court to draw the reasonable inference that the defendant is liable for the misconduct alleged.โ  
Id. (quoting Twombly, 550 U.S. at 556-57).  In deciding a motion under Rule 12(b)(6), a court

must the court accept legal conclusions.โ  Id. (quoting Hettinga, 677 F.4th at 476).  In determining 
whether a complaint fails to state a claim, a court may consider only the facts alleged in the 
complaint and โany documents either attached to or incorporated in the complaint,โ as well as 
โmatters of which the court may take judicial notice.โ  N. Am. Butterfly Assโn v. Wolf, 977 F.3d 
1244, 1249 (D.C. Cir. 2020) (alterations in original accepted, citation omitted).  
B.  Summary Judgment 
Summary judgment shall be granted โif the movant shows that there is no genuine dispute 
as to any material fact and the movant is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 
56(a).  Facts are only โโmaterialโ if a dispute over it might affect the outcome of a suit under the 
governing law,โ meaning that โfactual disputes that are โirrelevant or unnecessaryโ do not affect 
the summary judgment determination.โ  Mayorga v. Merdon, 928 F.3d 84, 89 (D.C. Cir. 2019) 
(quoting Holcomb v. Powell, 433 F.3d 889, 895 (D.C. Cir. 2006) (quoting Anderson v. Liberty

IV.  CONCLUSION  
The U.S. Constitution affords critical protections against Executive action like that ordered 
in EO 14230.  Government officials, including the President, may not โsubject[] individuals to 
โretaliatory actionsโ after the fact for having engaged in protected speech.โ  Hous. Cmty. Coll. Sys., 
595 U.S. at 474 (quoting Nieves, 587 U.S. at 398).  They may neither โuse the power of the State 
to punish or suppress disfavored expression,โ Vullo, 602 U.S. at 188, nor engage in the use of 
โpurely personal and arbitrary power,โ Yick Wo, 118 U.S. at 370.  In this case, these and other 
foundational protections were violated by EO 14230.  On that basis, this Court has found that EO 
14230 violates the Constitution and is thus null and void.  For the reasons explained, plaintiff is 
entitled to summary judgment and declaratory and permanent injunctive relief on Counts II 
through IX of the Amended Complaint.  The governmentโs motion to dismiss is denied. 
An order consistent with this Memorandum Opinion will be entered contemporaneously. 
Date:  May 2, 2025 
 
 
__________________________ 
BERYL A. HOWELL 
United States District Judge

  TABLE OF CONTENTS 
INTRODUCTION............................................................................................................. 1 
LEGAL STANDARDS AND RULE STATEMENTS ................................................... 3 
                    Shotgun Pleading ............................................................................................ 3 
                    Rule 12(b) & 56  ............................................................................................. 4
