I.  Plaintiffโs claims fail as to Section 1 of the Executive Order ................ 7 
II.  Plaintiffโs claims fail as to Section 2 of the Executive Order .............. 13 
III.  Plaintiffโs claims fail as to Section 3 of the Executive Order .............. 17 
IV.  Plantiffโs claims fail as to Section 4 of the Executive Order ............... 25 
V.  Plantiffโs claims fail as to Section 5 of the Executive Order ............... 28 
CONCLUSION ............................................................................................................... 32 
 
   
i 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 43     Filed 04/02/25     Page 3 of 34
The  U.S.  Department  of  Justice,  Federal  Communications  Commission,  Office  of 
Management and Budget, Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, Office of Personnel 
Management, General Services Administration, Office of the Director of National Intelligence, the 
United States of America, Pamela J. Bondi, Brendan Carr, Russell T. Vought, Andrea R. Lucas, 
Charles Ezell, Stephen Ehekian, and Tulsi Gabbard (collectively, โDefendantsโ), respectfully 
move this Court to dismiss the Complaint.   
INTRODUCTION 
On March 6, President Trump issued Executive Order 14,230 (the โExecutive Orderโ).  The 
Executive  Order  lays  out  the  Presidentโs  concerns  about  the  law  firm  Perkins  Coie  LLP 
(โPlaintiffโ)  in  matters  related  to  election  integrity,  national  security,  and  discriminatory 
employment practices.  In light of those considerations, the Executive Order directs a review of 
Perkins Coie to ensure that the Federal Governmentโs dealings with the firm are consistent with 
the national security of the United States and other public interests.  And it seeks to ensure that 
taxpayer funds are not in any way diverted to support unlawful or unsavory practices thatโif they 
should be permitted at allโmust be financed by the private dime.  
Plaintiffโs 172-paragraph complaint raising nine separate legal claims only obscures what 
is a straightforwardโand straightforwardly legalโExecutive Order.  Try as it might to frame the 
Executive Order as โpunitiveโ or a โsanction,โ the preamble in Section 1 and the operative sections 
of the Executive Order, Sections 2, 3, 4, and 5, act within the bounds of established executive 
authority. 
As to the Section 1 preamble, Plaintiffโs lawsuit carries with it a dangerous risk of muzzling 
the Executive.  No less than Plaintiff, the government has a right to speak which encompasses the 
statements in Section 1.   
1 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 43     Filed 04/02/25     Page 4 of 34
Section 2 of the Executive Order directs that agencies โreviewโ whether โactive security 
clearancesโ held by Plaintiffโs employees โare consistent with the national interest.โ  EO 14230 
ยง 2.  Plaintiff does not and cannot argue that it should have security clearance privileges if contrary 
to the national interest.  As detailed herein, courts have long held that on such matters the President 
is entitled to great deference.   
Section 3 of the Executive Order seeks to cancel any contracts for which Perkins Coie is 
hired to perform services.  The Executive Order specifies that, among other goals, Section 3 seeks 
to ensure that there is no transfer of taxpayer dollars to entities that engage in racial discrimination. 
Executive use of the procurement power to advance social policy has long been held to be on the 
firmest possible grounds of authority:  The express or implied authorization of Congress.  
Section 4 directs the Attorney General and the Chair of the Equal Employment Opportunity 
Commission (โEEOCโ) to review whether Perkins Coie and like employers are violating the civil 
rights lawsโin other words, to do what it was already the EEOCโs job to do.  Again, this is firmly 
within the prerogative of the Executive. 
In Section 5 the Executive Order directs agencies to issue guidance as to what access 
Plaintiffโs employees should have to government buildings and government officials, consistent 
with national security and applicable law, as well as examine the propriety of hiring employees 
from Plaintiffโs firm.  While Plaintiffโs claims are unripe as no agency has issued the guidance the 
order calls for.  The parameters of access to executive branch staff, offices, and employment are 
well within the rights of the Executive.  Try as Plaintiff might to describe potential impacts on the 
right to counsel, all of these assertions are pure conjecture and speculation.  The guidanceโwhich 
must be consistent with the lawโhas yet to be issued and therefore there is no actual controversy 
before this Court. 
2 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 43     Filed 04/02/25     Page 5 of 34
The Executive Order directs agencies to do what they should already be doing, declines to 
contract with entities who act inconsistently with valid social policies regarding discrimination, 
and calls for the lawful examination of security clearances and government access of employees 
of Plaintiffโs firm.  The law does not support Plaintiffโs claims as to Sections 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5; and 
as to Section 5 specifically, Plaintiffโs claim is at best too early and, as any guidance will be 
consistent with the law, will eventually fail on the merits.  Accordingly, this Court should dismiss 
the Complaint.    
LEGAL STANDARDS AND RULE STATEMENTS 
Shotgun Pleading 
  Each count of the Complaint begins with a paragraph stating, โPlaintiff repeats and 
realleges the allegations set forth in each of the preceding paragraphs as if fully set forth herein.โ  
See Compl. ยถยถ 85, 99, 106, 117, 126, 136, 144, 157, 165.  The Complaint does not limit โthe 
preceding paragraphsโ to those relevant to or illustrative of the legal and factual basis for each 
individual count, but incorporates every paragraph, including any preceding counts, count after 
count.  As an example, Count IX necessarily includes every preceding paragraph, including those 
in Counts IโVIII.  From a practical perspective, this severely handicaps the Defendantsโ and the 
Courtโs ability to ascertain the particulars of Plaintiffโs challenges to the various sections of the 
Executive Order, including which allegations and claims in the Complaint pertain to which 
sections of the Executive Order. 
The D.C. Circuit has emphasized that FED. R. CIV. P. 8 โunderscore[s] the emphasis placed 
on clarity and brevity by the federal pleading rules.โ  Ciralsky v. CIA, 355 F.3d 661, 668โ69 (D.C. 
Cir. 2004).  This case demonstrates why.  Plaintiffโs imprecise practice here only complicates 
Defendantsโ task in moving for dismissal and the Courtโs ability to assess these arguments.  Indeed, 
3 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 43     Filed 04/02/25     Page 6 of 34
Plaintiffโs Complaint in this respect is a paradigm example of a โshotgun pleading.โ  See Weiland 
v. Palm Beach Cnty. Sheriffโs Office, 792 F.3d 1313, 1321โ23 (11th Cir. 2015).  Defendants reserve 
the right to include in any follow-on briefing additional argument or bases for dismissal or 
judgment to the extent Plaintiff clarifies their claims in a manner not clearly evident on the face of 
its Complaint and TRO Motion.  To provide some structure regarding this overbroad shotgun 
Complaint, Defendants have organized this motion to dismiss by addressing what appear to be 
Plaintiffโs challenges to each section of the Executive Order. 
Rule 12(b) & 56 
On a Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss, the Court must โaccept the well-pleaded factual 
allegations as true and draw all reasonable inferences from those allegations in the plaintiffโs 
favor.โ  Air Excursions LLC v. Yellen, 66 F.4th 272, 277 (D.C. Cir. 2023).  The factual allegations 
โmust still be enough to raise a right to relief above the speculative level,โ and โthe Court need not 
accept inferences drawn by plaintiff if those inferences are not supported by the facts set out in the 
complaint.โ  Langeman v. Garland, 88 F.4th 289, 294 (D.C. Cir. 2023).  The Court may also 
consider โany documents either attached to or incorporated in the complaint,โ โmatters of which 
[the Court] may take judicial notice,โ and matters of public record.  EEOC v. St. Francis Xavier 
Parochial Sch., 117 F.3d 621, 625 (D.C. Cir. 1997); Sheppard v. United States, 640 F. Supp. 2d 29, 
32 (D.D.C. 2009).  For a motion brought under Rule 12(b)(1), the Court may consider the 
complaint  โsupplemented  by  undisputed  facts  evidenced  in  the  record  or  the  complaint 
supplemented by undisputed facts plus the courtโs resolution of disputed facts.โ  Sheppard, 640 
F. Supp. 2d at 32.  Summary judgment under Rule 56(a) may be granted only if โthere is no genuine 
dispute as to any material fact,โ including based on information outside the pleadings, and โthe 
movant is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.โ 
4 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 43     Filed 04/02/25     Page 7 of 34
  Plaintiff raises an ultra vires claim (Count I), due process claims (Counts II and III), an 
equal protection claim (Count IV), First Amendment claims (Counts V, VI, VII), and right-to-
counsel claims (Counts VIII and IX).   
  An ultra vires challenge such as that brought in Count I are โavailable only for the narrow 
purpose of obtaining injunctive relief against agency action taken in excess of its delegated powers 
and contrary to a specific prohibition in the law.โ  Fed. Express Corp. v. U.S. Depโt of Commerce, 
39 F.4th 756, 765 (D.C. Cir. 2022).  They are subject to a โdemanding standard.โ  Id. at 765.  Such 
claims are โconfined to extreme agency error where the agency has stepped so plainly beyond the 
bounds of its statutory authority, or acted so clearly in defiance of it, as to warrant the immediate 
intervention  of  an  equity  court.โ    Id.  at  764  (cleaned  up).    โOnly  error  that  is  patently  a 
misconstruction of [a statute], that disregards a specific and unambiguous statutory directive, or 
that violates some specific command of a statute will support relief.โ  Id. (cleaned up).  Further, to 
state an ultra vires claim properly, a plaintiff must show โthere is no alternative procedure for 
reviewโ of its claim.  Id. at 763.   
  Plaintiff raises a procedural due process challenge and a void-for-vagueness due process 
challenge in Counts II and III.  โA procedural due process claim consists of two elements: 
(i) deprivation by state action of a protected interest in life, liberty, or property, and (ii) inadequate 
state process.โ  Reed v. Goertz, 598 U.S. 230, 236 (2023); see also English v. District of Columbia, 
717 F.3d 968, 972 (D.C. Cir. 2013) (โThe procedural due process protections under the Fifth and 
Fourteenth Amendments are the same.โ).  Whether the process provided is adequate depends on 
โ(1) the importance of the private interest at stake, (2) the risk of an erroneous deprivation of the 
interest because of the procedures used and the probable value of additional procedural safeguards, 
and (3) the governmentโs interests, including the cost of additional procedures.โ  English, 717 F.3d 
5 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 43     Filed 04/02/25     Page 8 of 34
at 972.  And โ[t]he Due Process Clause prohibits the Government from taking away someoneโs 
life, liberty, or property under a criminal law so vague that it fails to give ordinary people fair 
notice of the conduct it punishes, or so standardless that it invites arbitrary enforcement.โ  Kincaid 
v. Govโt of the District of Columbia, 854 F.3d 721, 728 (D.C. Cir. 2017) (Kavanaugh, J.) (internal 
quotation marks omitted).   
  Plaintiff also raises an equal protection claim in Count IV, based on a class-of-one theory.  
To bring such a claim, a plaintiff must โallege that she has been intentionally treated differently 
from others similarly situated and that there is no rational basis for the difference in treatment.โ  
Willowbrook v. Olech, 528 U.S. 562, 564 (2000).  โClass-of-one plaintiffs must show an extremely 
high degree of similarity between themselves and the persons to whom they compare themselves.โ  
Quezada v. Marshall, 915 F. Supp. 2d 129, 135 (D.D.C. 2013).  And โ[e]ven at the motion to 
dismiss stage, a plaintiff alleging an equal protection violation must plead facts that establish that 
there is not any reasonable conceivable state of facts that could provide a rational basis for the 
classification.โ  Lillemoe v. U.S. Depโt of Agric., 344 F. Supp. 3d 215, 229 (D.D.C. 2018).   
  Plaintiff raises three claims based upon the First Amendment in Counts V, VI, and VII.  
First, Plaintiff claims that Defendants engaged in unconstitutional viewpoint discrimination.  
Second, Plaintiff argues that the Executive Orderโs requirement that government contractors 
disclose their business with Perkins Coie and whether that business is related to a government 
contract compels speech.  And third, Plaintiff alleges First Amendment retaliation.  To succeed on 
a First Amendment retaliation claim, a plaintiff must allege โ(1) he engaged in conduct protected 
under the First Amendment; (2) the defendant took some retaliatory action sufficient to deter a 
person of ordinary firmness in plaintiffโs position from speaking again; and (3) a causal link 
between the exercise of a constitutional right and the adverse action taken against him.โ  Aref v. 
6 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 43     Filed 04/02/25     Page 9 of 34
Lynch, 833 F.3d 242, 258 (D.C. Cir. 2016).  In the specific context of contractor speech, โfor a 
government employeeโs or contractorโs speech to have First Amendment protection, the employee 
or contractor must have (1) spoken as a citizen and (2) addressed matters of public concern.โ  
Ramey v. U.S. Marshals Serv., 755 F. Supp. 2d 88, 93 (D.D.C. 2010).  At the same time, โ[t]he 
government needs to be free to terminate both employees and contractors for poor performance.โ  
Bd. of Cnty. Commโrs v. Umbehr, 518 U.S. 668, 674 (1996).   
  Finally, Plaintiff raises two claims based on the right to counsel in Counts VIII and IX.  
The Sixth Amendment guarantees โthat a person brought to trial in any state or federal court must 
be afforded the right to the assistance of counsel.โ  Faretta v. California, 422 U.S. 806, 807 (1975).  
That right is โnot absoluteโ; it โcannot be insisted upon in a manner that will obstruct an orderly 
procedure in courts of justice,โ and the โpublic has a strong interest in the prompt, effective, and 
efficient administration of justice.โ  United States v. Burton, 584 U.S. 485, 489 (D.C. Cir. 1978).   
ARGUMENT 
I.  Plaintiffโs claims fail as to Section 1 of the Executive Order. 
Section 1 of the Executive Order contains a brief factual explanation for the operational 
elements of the Executive Order that describes Perkins Coieโs activities both in its capacity as a 
law firm offering legal representation and in its capacity as an employer.  As to its legal services, 
Section 1 explains that Perkins Coie was the law firm that โhired Fusion GPS,โ an opposition 
research firm that โmanufactured a false โdossierโ designed to steal an election.โ  EO 14230 ยง 1.  
It also describes how Perkins Coie has crossed ethical lines in election litigation such that it 
received a court sanction.  Id.  These statements are not seriously contested and are matters of 
public record.  
7 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 43     Filed 04/02/25     Page 10 of 34
As to Perkins Coieโs employment practices, the Executive Order noted that Perkins Coie 
โracially discriminates against its own attorneys and staff, and against applicants.โ  Id.  In 
particular, Perkins Coie โpublicly announced percentage quotas in 2019 for hiring and promotion 
on the basis of race and other categories prohibited by civil rights laws.โ  Id.  It also โproudly 
excluded applicants on the basis of race for its fellowships,โ and โmaintained these discriminatory 
practices until applicants harmed by them finally sued to enforce change.โ  Id.  These points, too, 
are not seriously contested.  The latter refers to a lawsuit instituted by the American Alliance for 
Equal Rights, which sued Perkins Coie because the law firmโs 1L diversity fellowship required 
โ[m]embership in a group historically underrepresented in the legal profession, including students 
of color, students who identify as LGBTQ+, and students with disabilities.โ  See Compl. ยถ 25, Am. 
All. for Equal Rights v. Perkins Coie LLP, No. 3:23-cv-1877 (N.D. Tex. Aug. 22, 2023), ECF No. 
1.  The suit was dismissed by stipulation after Perkins Coie replaced the fellowship program with 
a new program that did not contain discriminatory requirements.  Stipulation of Dismissal ยถยถ 3โ4, 
Am. All. for Equal Rights v. Perkins Coie LLP, No. 3:23-cv-1877 (N.D. Tex. Oct. 11, 2023), ECF 
No. 31.   
Only Counts II and III of the Complaint actually challenge Section 1.  In Count II, Plaintiff 
claims that โ[t]he Order harms Perkins Coieโs cognizable reputation interest by stigmatizing 
Perkins Coie as dishonest, untrustworthy and racially discriminatory.โ  Compl. ยถ 101.  And in 
Count III, Plaintiff claims that Section 1โs references to โdiversity, equity, and inclusionโ policies 
and โother categories prohibited by civil rights lawsโ are unconstitutionally vague.  Id. ยถ 109.   
Neither charge carries any water.  Count II raises a procedural due process challenge that 
requires Plaintiff to identify a โconstitutionally protected interest,โ Bowman v. Iddon, 848 F.3d 
1034, 1039 (D.C. Cir. 2017), and the typical plaintiff โlack[s] . . . any constitutional protection for 
8 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 43     Filed 04/02/25     Page 11 of 34
the interest in reputation,โ Siegert v. Gilley, 500 U.S. 226, 234 (1991).  A narrow exception to that 
general rule exists for โreputation-plus claim[s],โ which โrequire[] a plaintiff to identify an act of 
defamation made in conjunction with an adverse employment action.โ  Langeman, 88 F.4th at 296.  
โA defamatory statement must be false as well as defamatory,โ and for that reason โa statement of 
pure opinion cannotโ be โthe basis for a defamation claim.โ  Campbell v. District of Columbia, 
126 F. Supp. 3d 141, 150 (D.D.C. 2015) (internal quotation marks omitted). 
Count II fails because Plaintiff has not identified any defamatory act on the part of 
Defendants.  See Lamb v. Millennium Challenge Corp., 498 F. Supp. 3d 104, 115 (D.D.C. 2020) 
(noting that โa reputation-plus claim requires showing that the government made defamatory 
statements concerning the plaintiffโ).  Indeed, although the Complaint asserts that Section 1 is 
false in conclusory fashion, such statements need not be credited under the pleading standard, and 
Plaintiff does precious little to contest any particular fact in Section 1.  For instance, the Complaint 
does not dispute that Perkins Coie hired Fusion GPS, that Fusion GPS was involved in creating 
the fake dossier, and that the dossier was designed to interfere with the 2016 election.  Compl. 
ยถ 43.  Nor does the Complaint dispute that Perkins Coie was sanctioned in the course of its election 
litigation.  Id. ยถ 44.  The Complaint does reflect Plaintiffโs wish that Section 1 were longer, 
providing a laundry list of items which the Executive Order โd[id] not mention.โ  Id.  ยถยถ 43, 44.  
But the fact that the Executive Order was not almanac-length does not begin to suggest that 
anything in it was false.   
The only supposed falsity that the Complaint identifies is in Section 1โs assertion that 
Perkins Coie โracially discriminates against its own attorneys and staff.โ  Compl. ยถ 45 (quoting 
EO ยง 1).  But even then, that charge is conclusory and unsupported.  The Complaint cites to its 
practices in โ2019 and 2023โ as a defense against the charge that they have been engaged in racial 
9 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 43     Filed 04/02/25     Page 12 of 34
discrimination.  Id.  But those examples only prove the point.  See Horton v. Espindola, 319 
F. Supp. 3d 395, 400 (D.D.C. 2018) (โUnder the incorporation-by-reference doctrine, a defendant 
can submitโand the court can considerโa document that is not attached by the plaintiff, but is 
referred to in the complaint and integral to the plaintiffโs claim.โ).  Perkins Coie  publicly 
announced in 2019 that it signed the โMansfield Rule,โ which requires law firms to โcertify that 
women, lawyers of color, LGBTQ+ lawyers and lawyers with disabilities comprise at least 30 
percent  of  the  candidate  pool  for  significant  leadership  roles,  senior  lateral  openings  and 
promotions.โ    Perkins  Coie,  Press  Release,  Perkins  Coie  Adopts  Mansfield  Rule  to  Boost 
Leadership  Diversity  (Sept.  6,  2019)  (available  in  .pdf  form  at 
https://www.bing.com/search?q=perkins+coie+2019+press+release+mansfield+rule&form=QBL
H&sp=-1&lq=0&pq=&sc=0-
0&qs=n&sk=&cvid=B44AA6A85C4045D88B94CC00DC9A3124&ghsh=0&ghacc=0&ghpl=).     
In 2023, Perkins Coie represented to Vault that it has โset formal, measurable targets for increasing 
diversity in recruitment, retention, promotion, and/or leadership.โ  Perkins Coie 2023 Vault Law 
Firm Diversity Survey (available at https://media2.vault.com/14349412/perkins-coie.pdf); see 
Perkins  Coie  2024  Vault  Law  Firm  Diversity  Survey  (available  at 
https://media2.vault.com/14351750/perkins-coie.pdf).  In particular, Perkins Coie also told Vault 
that โ[s]trategic focus and intentionality are contributing to the advancement of our historically 
underrepresented attorneys,โ and followed that up by touting the percentages of new partners who 
are women or attorneys of color.  Perkins Coie 2023 Vault Law Firm Diversity Survey at 7. 
Moreover, Plaintiffโs Complaint provides additional grounds for statements in Section 1 
about Plaintiffโs diversity practices as Plaintiff repeatedly asserts its commitment to diversity.  
Compl. ยถยถ 45 (โIt is true that Perkins Coie has a longstanding commitment to diversity and 
10 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 43     Filed 04/02/25     Page 13 of 34
inclusion and has made, and continues to make, public statements advancing the ideals of diversity, 
equity, and inclusion.โ), 46 (โSection 1 relies on the false premise that, by promoting diversity in

into the coffers of such entities.  And it serves taxpayers to ensure that their dollars are not in any 
way traceable to the subsidization of โracial discrimination, falsified documents designed to 
weaponize the Government against candidates for office, and anti-democratic election changes 
that invite fraud and distrust.โ  EO 14230 ยง 3.   
Furthermore,  the  fact  that  a  funding  program  supports  one  point  of  view  does  not 
necessarily establish viewpoint discrimination against disfavored alternatives.  Rust v. Sullivan, 
500 U.S. 173 (1991).  There are no constitutional concerns with programs that encourage certain 
activities without providing funds for alternative options on the same issue.  There are only so 
 
3  Moreover,  Umbehrโs  retaliation  analysis  is  limited  to  current  government  employees  or 
contractors.  The Court specifically noted that its decision did โnot address the possibility of suits 
by  bidders  or  applicants  for  new  government  contracts  who  cannot  rely  on  [pre-existing] 
relationship[s].โ  Umbehr, 518 U.S. at 685. 
23 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 43     Filed 04/02/25     Page 26 of 34
many Government contracts to go around; โthe Government has not discriminated on the basis of 
viewpointโ merely by โfund[ing] one activity to the exclusion of the other.โ  Id. at 193.  By the 
same token, a โrefusal to fund protected activity, without more, cannot be equated with the 
imposition of a โpenaltyโ on that activity.โ  448 U.S. 297, 317, n.19 (1980).  Try as it might, Plaintiff 
cannot transmogrify the denial of a contract into a sanction that only the judicial branch can enter.  
Choosing  who  to  contract  with  is  not  โviewpoint  discriminationโ  or  โpunishmentโ  in  any 
meaningful sense of those words; it is merely a fact of life.  If Plaintiff dislikes the Governmentโs 
choices in this regard, the solution is that โa government entity is ultimately accountable to the 
electorate and the political process for its advocacy.โ  Pleasant Grove City, 555 U.S. at 469.  It is 
not to ask this Court for a remedy that it cannot give.   
And fifth, this Court should reject Plaintiffโs claims based on the right to counsel, because 
Plaintiff simply lacks standing to press them.  Plaintiff suggests that the Sixth Amendment is 
implicated because the Executive Order requires government contractors to disclose their business 
with Perkins Coie.  Butโagainโthe Executive Order only directs the termination of contracts 
under  which  Perkins  Coie  provides  services.    Plaintiff  never  explains  how  the  disclosure 
requirement would itself make it impossible to represent its clients in criminal or civil proceedings.    
And, unsurprisingly, the Complaint provides no examples.  The closest Plaintiff gets is 
when it alleges that one of its clients โis now considering retention of an alternative firm to 
represent it in connection with a DOJ investigation.โ  Compl. ยถ 76.  But that vignette proves the 
point.  Unless that DOJ investigation somehow implicates a government contract (which the 
Complaint does not allege), Section 3 has nothing to say about the matter.  And in any event, 
administrative investigationsโeven ones that โmight one day ripen into criminal chargesโโ
24 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 43     Filed 04/02/25     Page 27 of 34
frequently do not โimplicate the right to counsel.โ  Collins v. CFTC, 737 F. Supp. 1467, 1482 (N.D. 
Ill. 1990).  The right to counsel simply does not enter the picture as to Section 3.    
IV.  Plaintiffโs claims fail as to Section 4 of the Executive Order. 
Section 4 of the Executive Order directs the Chair of the Equal Employment Opportunity 
Commission to โreview the practices of representative large, influential, or industry leading law 
firms for consistency with Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 [42 U.S.C. ยง 2000e et seq.], 
including whether large law firms: reserve certain positions, such as summer associate spots, for 
individuals of preferred races; promote individuals on a discriminatory basis; permit client access 
on a discriminatory basis; or provide access to events, trainings, or travel on a discriminatory 
basis.โ  EO 14230 ยง 4(a).  It also directs the Attorney General, โin coordination with the Chair of 
the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and in consultation with State Attorneys General 
as appropriate,โ to investigate such matters with respect to such firms that do business with Federal 
entities.  Id. ยง 4(b).  
Plaintiff appears to challenge Section 4 on two grounds.  First, in Count III of the 
Complaint, Plaintiff claims Section 4 is unconstitutionally vague and violates due process because 
the section does not clearly define โdiversity, equity, and inclusionโ policies that may be subject 
to investigation by the EEOC.  See Compl. ยถยถ 109โ10.  As already explained, the language Plaintiff 
complains of as being overly vague is no less clear than the civil rights laws themselves.  For those 
and other reasons described above, this Court should reject Plaintiffโs attacks on Section 4 under 
Count III.  Second, in Count VII, Plaintiff complains that Section 4 violates the First Amendment 
because it constitutes โviewpoint discriminationโ and retaliation against Plaintiff for its support of 
diversity, equity, and inclusion policies.  See id. ยถยถ 145โ46, 151โ55. 
25 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 43     Filed 04/02/25     Page 28 of 34
To repeat, Section 4 merely directs the โreviewโ and โinvestigat[ion]โ of โthe practices of 
representative large, influential, or industry leading law firmsโ for consistency with the civil rights 
laws.  EO 14230 ยง 4.  That is already what the EEOC is supposed to be doing.  The EEOC is 
already โempowered . . . to prevent any person from engaging in any unlawful employment 
practiceโ under the civil rights laws.  42 U.S.C. ยง 2000e-5(a).  The EEOC is already required to 
make โreport[s] . . . to the President . . . on the cause of and means of eliminating discrimination,โ 
including in any industry the President directs the EEOC to review.  Id. ยง 2000e-4(e).  And 
members of the EEOC are already authorized to file charges against โemployer[s] . . . engaged in 
an unlawful employment practice.โ  Id. ยง 2000e-5(b).      
Thus, any supposed injury of Plaintiff is not traceable to the Executive Order and there is 
no plausible relief that the Court can give.  In short, Plaintiffโs supposed injury of being subject to 
a review for civil rights violations is unredressable.  Even if the President never issued the 
Executive Order, Plaintiff would still be subject to review by the EEOC and subject to potential 
legal action from the EEOCโjust like any other employer in the country.  The only relief that 
would โredressโ Plaintiffโs injury is not an injunction against the Executive Order, but rather an 
injunction granting Plaintiff immunity from civil rights laws applicable to all โrepresentative large, 
influential, or industry leading law firms.โ   
For  similar  reasons,  this  Court  should  reject  Plaintiffโs  claim  of  First  Amendment 
retaliation even if it were to reach the merits.  To succeed on a First Amendment retaliation claim, 
a plaintiff must allege โ(1) he engaged in conduct protected under the First Amendment; (2) the 
defendant took some retaliatory action sufficient to deter  a person of ordinary  firmness in 
plaintiffโs  position  from  speaking  again;  and  (3) a  causal  link  between  the  exercise  of  a 
constitutional right and the adverse action taken against him.โ  Aref v. Lynch, 833 F.3d 242, 258 
26 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 43     Filed 04/02/25     Page 29 of 34
(D.C. Cir. 2016).  โTo satisfy the causation link, a plaintiff must allege that his or her constitutional 
speech was the โbut forโ cause of the defendants' retaliatory action,โ Doe v. D.C., 796 F.3d 96, 107 
(D.C. Cir. 2015); that is, the plaintiff must allege that the retaliatory action โwould not have been 
taken absent the retaliatory motive,โ Houston Community College System v. Wilson, 595 U.S. 468, 
477 (2022). 
Even assuming Plaintiff engaged in protected conduct, Plaintiff cannot demonstrate the 
requisite causal link.  Even before the Executive Order was issued, this Administration had begun 
taking steps consistent with the view that certain DEI practices, misapplied, could constitute a 
violation of Title VII.  See EO 14173 of Jan. 21, 2025, 90 Fed. Reg. 8633 (Jan. 31, 2025) (โEnding 
Illegal Discrimination and Restoring Merit-Based Opportunityโ).  EO 14173, issued more than a 
month before the challenged Executive Order, directed, among other things, Federal agencies to 
take appropriate action to โadvance in the private sectorโ merit-based opportunity, EO 14173 
ยง 4(a), and to enforce civil rights laws and combat illegal private-sector DEI policies and practices, 
id. ยง 2; see also id. ยง 4(b) (requiring plan for compliance investigations going after illegal 
discrimination  in  large,  private  entities);  supra  Part  I  (regarding  EEOC/DOJ  press  release 
concerning DEI-related guidance).  It should not be surprising, then, that an executive order 
concerning a large private law firm included a provision like Section 4, directing EEOC โreviewโ 
of practices of โrepresentative large, influential, or industry leading law firms,โ as part of the 
Administrationโs broader efforts.  Thus, Plaintiff cannot show that the Section 4 review, the alleged 
retaliatory action, โwould not have been taken absent the [alleged] retaliatory motive.โ  Plaintiffโs 
retaliation claim cannot succeed. 
At bottom, the Administration has raised legitimate legal issues of just how far DEI policies 
and programs can go and whether such policies cross the line into illegal discrimination under Title 
27 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 43     Filed 04/02/25     Page 30 of 34
VII.  The Court should not use its equitable and other powers to excuse Plaintiff from the scope of 
a review of multiple law firms on this issue.  Plaintiff may believe its practices are not illegal, but 
it is not entitled to a โfree passโ from a legitimate review of multiple law firmsโ employment 
practices.   
V.  Plaintiffโs claims fail as to Section 5 of the Executive Order.     
Finally, Section 5 of the Executive Order concerns Federal hiring, access to government 
buildings, and interaction with government employees.  As relevant, Section 5 provides three 
directives.  First, agency heads โshall, to the extent permitted by law, provide guidance limiting 
official access from Federal Government buildings to employees of Perkins Coie when such access 
would threaten the national security of or otherwise be inconsistent with the interests of the United 
States.โ  EO 14230 ยง 5(a).  Second, agency heads โshall provide guidance limiting Government 
employees acting in their official capacity from engaging with Perkins Coie employees to ensure 
consistency with the national security and other interests of the United States.โ  Id.  Third, 
โ[a]gency officials shall, to the extent permitted by law, refrain from hiring employees of Perkins 
Coie, absent a waiver from the head of the agency, made in consultation with the Director of the 
Office of Personnel Management, that such hire will not threaten the national security of the United 
States.โ  Id. ยง 5(b). 
Plaintiff raises a variety of challenges to Section 5.  This Court should reject them as unripe 
without even reaching the merits.  โ[A] claim is not ripe for adjudication if it rests upon contingent 
future events that may not occur as anticipated, or indeed may not occur at all.โ  In re Al-Nashiri, 
47 F.4th at 826.  That describes Plaintiffโs claims against Section 5 to a tee.  Section 5 directs 
agency heads to โprovide guidanceโ on โlimitingโ access to government buildings and interactions 
with government employees.  It does not outright ban such access.  Plaintiff can only guess the 
28 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 43     Filed 04/02/25     Page 31 of 34
degree to which agency heads will limit government access, and indeed Section 5 directs such 
agency heads only to do so โto the extent permitted by law.โ  Perhaps agency heads will limit their 
guidance  to  prohibiting  Plaintiff  from  entering  Government  locations  storing  sensitive 
information, which no member of the public has a right to access.  Perhaps the agency heads and 
the OPM director will, as a matter of course, waive the hiring freeze in all cases but the ones posing 
the most egregious threats to national security.  Either way, Plaintiff cannot bring this challenge on 
nothing more than rank speculation of what agency heads might do in response to Section 5 and 
without concrete examples of harm alleged to have been caused by Section 5.     
That lack of ripeness infects the entire challenge against Section 5.  Plaintiff alleges that 
the Executive Order โimpairs Perkin Coieโs ability to follow its chosen profession by limiting . . . 
its ability to represent clients in court and before agencies.โ  Compl. ยถ 101.  It accuses the order of 
โbarring  Perkins  Coie  from  . . .  interacting  with  federal  employees[]  and  accessing  federal 
buildings.โ  Id. ยถ 123.  It cries alarm that the order โconditions . . . access to government facilitiesโ 
on โpolitical support or affiliation.โ  Id. ยถ 132.  And it lambasts the order for โsignificantly 
impair[ing] Perkins Coieโs ability to advance clientsโ interests before the government.โ  Id. ยถยถ 160โ
61.  But at the end of the day, Plaintiff is challenging a Section of the EO that tells agency heads 
only to โissue guidance.โ  It therefore cannot plausibly allege that Section 5 caused it injury on the 
basis of guidance which has not been issued.  There is simply no case for this Court to hear on this 
subject.   
Even if this Court were to proceed to the merits, it should dismiss Plaintiffโs claims 
challenge to Section 5.  Start with Plaintiffโs ultra vires claim, which remarkably suggests that 
Federal agencies lack any authority to control over who can enter their buildings or interact with 
their employees on official business.  There is no constitutional right to enter government buildings 
29 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 43     Filed 04/02/25     Page 32 of 34
at will, U.S. Postal Serv. v. Council of Greenburgh Civic Assโns, 453 U.S. 114, 129 (1981), and 
โ[t]he State, no less than a private owner of property, has power to preserve the property under its 
control for the use to which it is lawfully dedicated,โ Greer v. Spock, 424 U.S. 828, 836 (1976).  
As  before,  Plaintiff  might  think  that  Defendants  plan  to  exercise  this  authority  in  an 
unconstitutional manner (though, again, no guidance has yet issued), but that is reason to raise a 
constitutional claim, not an ultra vires claim.  Cf. Eagle Trust Fund v. USPS, 811 F. Appโx 669, 
670 (D.C. Cir. 2020).  
Those constitutional claims, however, fare no better.  Once again, Plaintiff lacks standing 
to press its due process claims, because it cannot point to any injury traceable to Section 5 of the 
Executive Order.  Furthermore, whether Plaintiff received adequate process depends on the 
โimportance of the private interest at stake,โ English, 717 F.3d at 972, and the โinterest at stakeโ 
depends on what guidance the agency heads will issue.  Until then, Plaintiffโs conclusory assertion 
that the Executive Order โdeprives Perkins Coie of its liberty interest in its First Amendment right 
to petition the governmentโ is due no weight at all.  Compl. ยถ 101.   
Plaintiffโs equal protection claim fails as well.  According to Plaintiff, there is not โeven a 
rational justification for the Order.โ  Id. ยถ 123.  But that ignores the actual text of Section 5.  Every 
part of Section 5 is tied to โthe national securityโ of the United States.  EO 14230 ยง 5.  Agency 
heads are directed to โlimit official accessโ only when โaccess would threaten the national security 
of or otherwise be inconsistent with the interests of the United States.โ  They are directed to โlimit 
Government  employees  acting  in  their  official  capacity  from  engaging  with  Perkins  Coie 
employeesโ only โto ensure consistency with the national security and other interests of the United 
States.โ  And the hiring freeze may be overridden so long as the agency head and the OPM Director 
30 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 43     Filed 04/02/25     Page 33 of 34
determines โthat such hire will not threaten the national security of the United States.โ  In other 
words, Section 5 clearly states a rational justification.   
And  Plaintiffโs  First Amendment  claims  falter  for  similar  reasons.   To  state  a  First 
Amendment retaliation claim, a plaintiff must allege โa causal link between the exercise of a 
constitutional right and the adverse action taken against him.โ  Aref, 833 F.3d at 258.  Even 
assuming Plaintiff engaged in protected conduct Plaintiff cannot demonstrate the requisite causal 
link.  Section 5 is not tied to speech; it is tied to the โnational securityโ and the โinterestsโ of the 
United States, โto the extent permitted by law.โ  EO 14230 ยง 5.   
Finally, Plaintiff appears to rest heavily on the notion that Section 5 violates its clientsโ 
right to counsel.  Again, until agency heads issue guidance, Plaintiff can only speculate as to 
whether anyoneโs right to counsel will be affected at all by Section 5.  Regardless, โ[t]he 
constitutional right to choice of counsel . . . is not absolute.โ  United States v. Friedman, 849 F.2d 
1488, 1490 (D.C. Cir. 1988).  It โmust be balanced against the governmentโs interest in the fair, 
orderly, and effective administration of the courts which, in a given case, may require an accused 
to resort to his second choice of counsel.โ  United States v. Koblitz, 803 F.2d 1523, 1528 (11th Cir. 
1986).  And the right is โqualified by the need to avoid undermining public confidence in the 
integrity of the legal system.โ  United States v. Wheat, 813 F.2d 1399, 1401โ02 (9th Cir. 1987).   
Read as a whole, the Executive Order considered Plaintiffโs history in litigationโincluding 
a court sanction and involvement with Fusion GPS.  EO 14230 ยง 1.  And as to Section 5 itself, the 
Executive Order is preoccupied with the โnational securityโ and โinterestsโ of the United States.  
Id. ยง 5.  If completely unfettered access to government buildings and government employees in 
fact โthreaten[ed] the national securityโ of the United States, id., turning a blind eye to that threat 
would surely โundermine public confidence in the integrity of the legal systemโ (Wheat, 813 F.2d 
31 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 43     Filed 04/02/25     Page 34 of 34
at 1401โ02) and would impair โthe fair, orderly, and effective administration of the courts,โ 
Koblitz, 803 F.2d at 1528.  And if completely unfettered access would not threaten the national 
security or interests of the United States, then Section 5 will have no impact whatsoever on Plaintiff 
and it would lack any injury to complain of.  Either way, the Court should dismiss this claim as 
well.   
CONCLUSION 
  The Court should dismiss the Complaint and grant judgment to Defendants.  
Dated: April 2, 2025  Respectfully submitted, 
  Washington, DC   
 
  CHAD MIZELLE  
Acting Associate Attorney General 
 
 
/s/ Richard Lawson       
RICHARD LAWSON 
Deputy Associate Attorney General 
950 Pennsylvania Avenue, NW 
Washington, DC 20530 
Telephone: (202) 445-8042

documents.text:
Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 36     Filed 03/26/25     Page 1 of 21
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA 
 
PERKINS COIE LLP,   
   
Plaintiff,   
  Civil Action No. 25-716 (BAH) 
v.   
  Judge Beryl A. Howell 
U.S. DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE, et al., 
 
Defendants. 
 
MEMORANDUM OPINION AND ORDER 
Though this adage is commonplace, and the tactic overused, it is called to mind by 
defendantsโ pending motion to disqualify this Court: โWhen you canโt attack the message, attack 
the messenger.โ  Defendants filed this motion less than two weeks after this Court issued a 
temporary restraining order barring defendants from enforcing against plaintiff Perkins Coie LLP 
three of the five sections of Executive Order 14230 (โEO 14230โ), issued by President Donald J. 
Trump on March 6, 2025, 90 Fed. Reg. 11781 (Mar. 11, 2025), targeting the law firm with punitive 
measures due to the law firmโs representation of clients whom the President dislikes or who sought 
relief through litigation that the President opposes.  When the U.S. Department of Justice engages 
in this rhetorical strategy of ad hominem attack, the stakes become much larger than only the 
reputation of the targeted federal judge.  This strategy is designed to impugn the integrity of the 
federal judicial system and blame any loss on the decision-maker rather than fallacies in the 
substantive legal arguments presented.  
The opportunity presented by the defendantsโ motion, which invokes 28 U.S.C. ยง 455(a) 
to disqualify this Court, is welcomed to set the record straight, because facts matter.  To begin, this 
Court agrees wholeheartedly with defendants that โ[f]air proceedings free from any suggestion of 
impartiality are essential to the integrity of our countryโs judiciary.โ   Defendantsโ Mot. to 
1 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 36     Filed 03/26/25     Page 2 of 21
Disqualify Judge Beryl Howell (โDefs.โ Mot.โ) at 1, ECF No. 34.  No judicial ruling exists in a 
vacuum but rests on the facts presented in โCasesโ or โControversiesโ necessary for the exercise 
of a federal courtโs jurisdiction, U.S. Const. art. III, ยง 2, and every litigating party deserves a fair 
and impartial hearing to determine both what the material facts are and how the law best applies 
to those facts.  That fundamental promise, however, does not entitle any partyโnot even those 
with the power and prestige of the President of the United States or a federal agencyโto demand 
adherence to their own version of the facts and preferred legal outcome.  โFactfinding,โ after all, 
โis the basic responsibility of district courts,โ Pullman-Standard v. Swint, 456 U.S. 273, 291 (1982) 
(citation omitted, alteration accepted), and โ[i]t is emphatically the province and duty of the 
judicial department to say what the law is,โ Marbury v. Madison, 5 U.S. (1 Cranch) 137, 177 
(1803).   
This reminder about the role of the federal courts seems necessary given the opening line 
in defendantsโ pending motion, expressing โthe need to curtail ongoing improper encroachments 
of President Trumpโs Executive Power playing out around the country.โ  Defs.โ Mot. at 1.  This 
line, which sounds like a talking point from a member of Congress rather than a legal brief from 
the United States Department of Justice, has no citation to any legal authority for the simple reason 
that  the  notion  expressed  reflects  a  grave  misapprehension  of  our  constitutional  order.  
Adjudicating whether an Executive Branch exercise of power is legal, or not, is actually the job of 
the federal courts, and not of the President or the Department of Justice, though vigorous and 
rigorous defense of executive actions is both expected and helpful to the courts in resolving legal 
issues.  Defendants then proceed, in the second line of their pending motion, to describe as 
โmeritlessโ every lawsuit challenging the Presidentโs โagenda that the American people elected 
him to carry out.โ  Id.  This blanket denigration of the merits of all the lawsuits filed across the 
2 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 36     Filed 03/26/25     Page 3 of 21
country certainly reflects palpable frustration with court rulings issued to pause, temper, or reverse 
Trump  Administration  actions,  but  this  is  a  testament  to  the  fact  that  this  country  has  an 
independent judiciary that adheres to an impartial adjudication process, without being swayed 
merely because the federal government appears on one side of a case and the President wishes a 
particular result.  
While obviously not able to speak to the merits of all the cases โaround the countryโ 
provoking defendantsโ frustration, a quick survey of the cases over which this Court is presiding 
challenging the current Administrationโs actions show that, contrary to the defendantsโ posturing, 
the outcomes have followed the facts and the law.  When the facts and applicable law appear likely 
to favor the actions taken by the current administration, for example, this Court has ruled in the 
governmentโs favor.  See, e.g., Min. Order, U.S. Inst. of Peace v. Jackson, No. 25-cv-804-BAH 
(D.D.C. Mar. 19, 2025) (denying motion for a temporary restraining order filed by plaintiffs in a 
case against President Trump and ten other Executive Branch defendants for terminating ten board 
members and the acting president of the U.S. Institute of Peace).  In another case, even the 
government conceded that binding Supreme Court precedent required the legal result reached by 
this Court if the facts were found to be sufficiently similar to that precedent, which the Court found 
they were.  See Wilcox v. Trump, -- F. Supp. 3d --, 2025 WL 720914, at *10 (D.D.C. Mar. 6, 2025); 
id.  at  *1  (โHumphreyโs  Executor  remains  binding  on  this  Court,  as  defendants  rightly 
acknowledge.โ (citing Defs.โ Oppโn at 8 n.2)); Defs.โ Cross-Mot. for Summ. J. & Oppโn to Pls.โ 
Mot. for Summ. J. at 8 n.2, Wilcox v. Trump, No. 25-cv-334, ECF No. 23 (D.D.C.) (filed Feb. 21, 
2025) (โ[T]he government acknowledges that whatever little remains of Humphreyโs Executor is 
binding on this Court until overturned by the Supreme Court.โ).  Thus, in the latter case, the action 
3 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 36     Filed 03/26/25     Page 4 of 21
taken by the President was declared null and void, since the facts and applicable law entitled the 
plaintiff to a favorable judgment.  The neutral administration of justice required no less.   
The D.C. Circuit has warned that consideration of a motion for disqualification โis never 
taken lightly,โ since โ[i]n the wrong hands, a disqualification motion is a procedural weaponโ that, 
โ[i]f supported only by rumor, speculation, or innuendo,โ might be used, among other nefarious 
purposes, as โa means to tarnish the reputation of a federal judge,โ United States v. Microsoft 
Corp., 253 F.3d 34, 108 (D.C. Cir. 2001) (en banc) (per curiam), or to โreduce[] the judicial process 
to little more than a skirmish in a partisan battle,โ In re Flynn, 973 F.3d 74, 85 (D.C. Cir. 2020) 
(en banc) (per curiam) (Griffith, J., concurring).  This larger concern about the overall damage to 
the rule of law and the federal judicial system from the feckless impugning of the decision-making 
process of individual federal judges has prompted Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr., to criticize 
โregrettabl[e] . . . attemptsโ by โ[p]ublic officials . . . to intimidate judges,โ including by 
โsuggesting  political  bias  in  the  judgeโs  adverse  rulings  without  a  credible  basis  for  such 
allegations.โ  John G. Roberts, Jr., 2024 Year End Rep. on the Fed. Judiciary 7 (Dec. 31, 2024), 
https://perma.cc/QU5A-r9YB.      
Here, defendants rely only on โspeculation[ and] innuendoโ in seeking to get another Judge 
assigned to preside over this case.  The clear absence of any legitimate basis for disqualification 
requires denial of the pending motion.  See, e.g., United States v. Haldeman, 559 F.2d 31, 139 
n.360 (D.C. Cir. 1976) (โ[I]n assessing the reasonableness of a challenge to his impartiality, each

I.  LEGAL STANDARD 
A judge must โdisqualify himself in any proceeding in which his impartiality might 
reasonably be questioned,โ 28 U.S.C. ยง 455(a), or โ[w]here he has a personal bias or prejudice 
concerning a party,โ id. ยง (b)(1).  This statute sets a high bar under which โrecusal must be limited 
to truly extraordinary cases.โ  Cobell v. Kempthorne, 455 F.3d 317, 332 (D.C. Cir. 2006); see also, 
e.g., United States v. Pollard, 959 F.2d 1011, 1023 (D.C. Cir. 1992) (โ[D]isqualification of a judge 
is not lightly granted,โ since โthat reliefโ is โextraordinary.โ).  As a result, the party moving for 
disqualification carries a โheavy burdenโ of proof to succeed.  Cobell, 455 F.3d at 332.  A courtโs 
โjudicial rulings alone almost neverโ satisfy this standard.  Liteky v. United States, 510 U.S. 540, 
555 (1994) (citing United States v. Grinnell Corp., 384 U.S. 563, 583 (1966)); see also SEC v. 
Loving Spirit Found. Inc., 392 F.3d 486, 493 (D.C. Cir. 2004) (โ[R]ulings resting on record 
evidence โalmost never constitute a valid basis for a bias or partiality motion.โโ (quoting Liteky, 
510 U.S. at 555)).  Instead, as the Supreme Court has explained, adverse rulings are โ[a]lmost 
invariably . . . proper grounds for appeal, not for recusal.โ  Liteky, 510 U.S. at 555.  Moreover, 
judicial recusal is required โโif a reasonable person, knowing all the circumstances, would expect 
that the judge would have actual knowledgeโ of his interest or bias in the case.โ  Sao Paulo State 
of Federative Republic of Braz. v. Am. Tobacco Co., 535 U.S. 229, 232-33 (2002) (emphasis in 
original) (quoting Liljeberg v. Health Servs. Acquisition Corp., 486 U.S. 847, 861 (1988)); see also 
Microsoft Corp. v. United States, 530 U.S. 1301, 1302 (2000) (Statement of Chief Justice 
Rehnquist on decision not to recuse) (noting that, under ยง 455(a), the โinquiry is an objective one,

and circumstancesโ); United States v. Hite, 769 F.3d 1154, 1172 (D.C. Cir. 2014) (reiterating that

Similarly, when a motion for disqualification relies on other grounds, recusal is improper 
unless the moving party can show that the judge has โdisplayed deep-seated and unequivocal 
antagonism that would render fair judgment impossible.โ  Liteky, 510 U.S. at 556; id. at 558

various codes governing judicial conduct.  Republican Party of Minn. v. White, 536 U.S. 765, 779

by whom, determining where venue for a criminal charge properly lies may not become clear until 
the investigation has sufficiently progressed to assess who is involved in the criminal conduct, 
where relevant conduct occurred, and the precise charges to be brought.  To be sure, by the time 
the grand jury returns an indictment, โthe government must show that โvenue is proper with respect 
to each count charged.โโ  United States v. Slatten, 865 F.3d 767, 788 (D.C. Cir. 2017) (quoting 
United States v. Lam Kwong-Wah, 924 F.2d 298, 301 (D.C. Cir. 1991)).  Here, the Crime Fraud 
Decision was issued several months before any indictment was filed in the Southern District of 
Florida arising from this aspect of the grand juryโs work. 
In sum, mere disagreements with the prior legal rulings of this Court do not โconstitute a 
valid basisโ for disqualification.  Liteky, 510 U.S. at 555.   
B.  November 2023 Speech 
Defendants also point to a single line in a speech delivered by this Court in November 
2023,  upon  acceptance  of  an  award  from  the  Womenโs  White  Collar  Defense  Association 
(โWWCDAโ), Defs.โ Mot. at 3, a non-partisan, non-profit organization that promotes diversity in 
white-collar  and  other  defense  and  compliance  legal  work,  see  Membership  and  Mission, 
Womenโs White Collar Defense Assโn, https://www.wwcda.org/who-we-are/mission-goals-and-
membership-criteria (last visited Mar. 25, 2025).  The apolitical, nonpartisan theme of the remarks 
15 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 36     Filed 03/26/25     Page 16 of 21
defendants cite for purported bias was the importance of facts in the legal profession, the body 
politic, and American democracy.  See 2023 WWCDA Awards Gala Full Video (โWWCDA 
Videoโ)  at  1:45:11โ1:53:15  (Nov.  30,  2023),  YouTube, 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sNDnJWh1gzE.  To support these points, the speech drew on 
examples from history, including an anecdote about President Abraham Lincoln, see id. at 
1:47:25โ1:48:10, and quoted from a recent bestselling book by a Boston College professor of 
American history warning about one of the keys to the rise of authoritarianism being the dismissal 
of facts and reliance on โbig lies,โ see id. at 1:48:28โ1:49:40.  In further emphasis of this point, a 
single line of the speech reflected on then-recent experiences at the sentencings of individuals 
involved in the attack on the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021, stating that judges on this Court 
โregularly see the impact of โbig liesโ at the sentencing of hundreds, hundreds of individuals who 
have been convicted for offense conduct on January 6, 2021, when they disrupted the certification 
of the 2020 presidential election at the U.S. Capitol.โ  Id. at 1:49:41โ1:50:04.  This remark drew 
on observations of, and comments made by, defendants and their counsel about the motivations 
for many defendants to engage in this criminal conduct as stemming from their belief in a stolen 
election, despite the lack of any evidence showing any outcome dispositive election fraud in the 
2020 presidential election.   
Importantly, and contrary to defendantsโ assertions, see Defs.โ Mot. at 3, this speech never 
mentioned President Trump or took any political positions, nor named any of the media outlets, 
pundits or politicians cited by January 6 defendants and their counsel in court proceedings as the 
source for their mistaken belief in a stolen 2020 presidential election.  See generally WWCDA 
Video  at  1:45:11โ1:53:15.    To  the  extent  defendants  suggest  otherwise  and  even  point  an 
accusatory finger at President Trump as the person who must have been the source, that is their 
16

finger and not that of this Court.  Their motion twists and mischaracterizes the words actually 
spoken, seemingly adopting the partisan framing by a Republican member of Congress who filed 
the ethics complaint referenced by defendants against this Court.  Defs.โ Mot. at 3-4; see also April 
Rubin, Stefanik Urges Ethics Investigation into Judge Linked to Trump, Jan. 6 Cases, Axios (Dec. 
15,  2023),  https://www.axios.com/2023/12/15/stefanik-complaint-ethics-judge-trump.6    This 
same Republican member of Congress has filed a series of ethics complaints against other judges 
who issued rulings perceived to be adverse to President Trump.  See, e.g., Jose Pagliery, New York 
Tosses Stefanikโs Trump Court Complaint in Bank Fraud Civil Suit, The Daily Beast (June 3, 2024, 
8:01 PM), https://www.thedailybeast.com/new-york-tosses-rep-stefaniks-trump-court-complaint-
in-bank-fraud-civil-suit/ (reporting that an ethics complaint filed by the same Republican member 
of Congress against a New York state court judge overseeing a civil trial against President Trump 
was dismissed as โhaving . . . no basis on the facts presented to commence an investigationโ); 
Sophia Cai, Scoop: Stefanik Files Ethics Complaint Against Judge Merchan, Axios (May 21, 
2024), https://www.axios.com/2024/05/21/stefanik-ethics-complaint-judge-merchan-trump.  Two 
independent legal ethics experts characterized the ethics complaint filed against this Court as

https://www.americanbar.org/groups/criminal_justice/resources/magazine/2024-summer/ethics-

6   Other obvious sources for misinformation about a โstolenโ 2020 presidential election were certainly

lawsuit presided over by this Court returned a verdict of $148,169,000.00, in compensatory and punitive damages 
for defamation and intentional infliction of emotional distress in favor of two Georgia election workers against 
Rudolph W. Giuliani for his false public statements that the plaintiffs had engaged in election fraud when doing their 
job of counting ballots for the 2020 presidential election.  See Verdict Form, Freeman v. Giuliani, No. 21-cv-3354-
BAH, ECF No. 135 (D.D.C. Dec. 15, 2023). 
17

The  Supreme  Court  has  long  recognized  that  judges  are  โnot  only  permit[ted]  but 
encourage[d]โ to โstate their views on disputed legal issues outside the context of adjudication,โ 
including โin classes that they conduct, and in books and speeches.โ  Republican Party of Minn., 
536 U.S. at 779.  It is โcommonโ for judges to later โconfront[] a legal issue on which [they have] 
expressed an opinion while on the bench,โ including โin . . . speeches.โ  Id.  This reality does not 
undermine a judgeโs impartiality.  In the words of the D.C. Circuit, disqualification โwould be 
extraordinaryโ for remarks that โreflected what [a judge] learned, or what [the judge] thought [s]he 
learned, during . . . proceedingsโ in a case.  Microsoft Corp., 253 F.3d at 115.  โ[C]andid 
reflectionsโ about a โjudgeโs assessment of a defendantโs conductโ offered โon the basis of facts 
presented during the proceedings . . . simply do not establish bias or prejudice.โ  United States v. 
Fokker Servs. B.V., 818 F.3d 733, 751 (D.C. Cir. 2016) (internal quotation marks omitted) (quoting 
In re Barry, 946 F.2d 913, 914 (D.C. Cir. 1991)). 
โCandid reflectionsโ are exactly what the remarks at issue here offered, drawing on 
knowledge and experience from observing and presiding over many cases and trials arising out of 
the attack on the Capitol on January 6, 2021, and becoming intimately familiar with the facts of 
that day.  See, e.g., United States v. Warnagiris, No. 21-cr-382 (PLF), 2025 WL 341990, at *5 
(D.D.C. Jan. 30, 2025) (explaining the extensive investigations of the facts of January 6 cases and 
voluminous evidence presented in each case to support the prosecutions).  These cases were used 
to emphasize the importance of a generally applicable legal theme about the critical importance of 
accurate fact-finding to the legal process and to the broader health of our democracy.  As explained 
in the speech, a focus on โauthentic, reliable, and tested factsโ promotes confidence that all parties 
will receive fair processes and just outcomes in federal district courts and federal courts more

broadly.  WWCDA Video at 1:50:04โ1:51:05.  Put simply, the nonpartisan discussion of the 
importance of facts provides no basis for disqualification in this case. 
C.  The Instant Case 
Finally, as is clearly laid out in the โPurposeโ section of EO 14230, โissues of the Durham 
investigation, the Fusion GPS report, and the Mueller Report are central to the EO.โ  Defs.โ Mot. 
at 6; see also EO 14230, ยง 1, 90 Fed. Reg. at 11781.  Defendants take issue with what they call the 
Courtโs โconcerning and dismissive approach to the entire Durham Investigationโ and โ[t]he entire 
Fusion GPS fiasco.โ  Defs.โ Mot. at 6.  While styling this as an accusation about purported bias in 
the Courtโs โ[c]onduct,โ id., at its core, this objection appears to be that the Court has not given 
sufficient deference to how President Trump views these and other events as โdishonest and 
dangerous activity of the law firm,โ EO 14230, ยง 1, 90 Fed. Reg. at 11781, and โactions that 
threaten our elections, military strength, and national security,โ Fact Sheet: President Donald J. 
Trump  Addresses  Risks  from  Perkins  Coie  LLP,  The  White  House  (Mar.  6,  2025), 
https://www.whitehouse.gov/fact-sheets/2025/03/fact-sheet-president-donald-j-trump-adresses-
risks-from-perkins-coie-llp/.    While  the  President  and  his  administration  are  promoting  an 
expansive view of presidential authority and claimed that any decisions purportedly made in the 
name of national security are judicially nonreviewable, see, e.g., Tr. of Mar. 12, 2025, Temporary 
Restraining Order Hrโg (โTRO Hrโg Tr.โ) at 30:6โ35:12, ECF No. 22; see also id. at 45:23โ48:11 
(defense counsel explaining defendantsโ position that โthe President has that power, and that it is 
the right and prerogative of the President as the sole individual vested with Article II authority to 
exercise that prerogativeโ), that legally debatable claim is at the heart of the challenge in this case, 
see, e.g., id. at 18:7โ21:6 (plaintiffโs counsel articulating position that the Presidentโs conduct 
violated fundamental constitutional rights and that the use of โthe โnational securityโ words are a 
19 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 36     Filed 03/26/25     Page 20 of 21
pretextโ); id. at 62:24โ64:22 (plaintiffโs counsel further articulating plaintiffโs position that the 
Presidentโs actions exceeded his constitutional authority).  The mere fact that the Court, in an 
emergency hearing on a temporary restraining order held less than 24 hours after the filing of the 
motion, did not immediately adopt defendantsโ legal arguments about the level of deference owed 
to the President, even when a national security justification is asserted, does not mean bias exists 
when foundational constitutional principles and norms are also at stake.   
Moreover, defendantsโ motion mischaracterizes the discussion of Fusion GPS and the 
Mueller investigation.  While noting possible โbig differences of viewโ on these topics, the Court 
took โat face valueโ โ[t]he Presidentโs perspectiveโ on the issue and used this viewpoint to evaluate 
the likely legality of EO 14230.  TRO Hrโg Tr. at 32:15โ33:16; see also id. at 33:21โ43:14 
(questioning defendantsโ counsel about aspects of the legality of the order).  The Court recognized 
that President Trump is โcertainly entitled to his own beliefs, entitled to his preferred causes, and 
he is entitled to hold tight to his own dislikes.โ  Id. at 103:19-21.  As a legal matter, however, the 
Court found at this stage that โ[t]he Constitution protects all [Americans] . . . from the exercise of 
[the  Presidentโs]  targeted  power  based  on  those  dislikes,  to  bring  the  force  of  the  federal 
government down on the lawyers representing his political opponents and challengers to his 
political actions, as he has done here.โ  Id. at 103:22โ104:1.   
As this case continues, pursuant to the briefing schedule jointly proposed by the parties, 
Joint Status Report ยถ 3, ECF No. 25, and adopted by the Court, Order, ECF No. 26, the parties will 
have the opportunity to present relevant evidence and legal arguments, which will receive full, 
fair, and impartial consideration, as does every case before this Court.  To the extent the parties 
disagree with the final judgment entered, the normal judicial process of appeal applies.  See FED. 
20 
 

Case 1:25-cv-00716-BAH     Document 36     Filed 03/26/25     Page 21 of 21
R. APP. P. 4.  Defendantsโ disagreements, no matter how strong, with this Courtโs preliminary legal 
determinations simply provide no basis for disqualification.  Liteky, 510 U.S. at 555.   
III.  CONCLUSION AND ORDER 
For the reasons addressed above, defendantsโ motion to disqualify this Court pursuant to 
28 U.S.C. ยง 455, ECF No. 34, which relies only on speculation, innuendo, and basic legal 
disagreements that provide no basis for disqualification of a judge, must be denied.  Therefore, it 
is herebyโ 
ORDERED that defendantsโ Motion to Disqualify Judge Beryl Howell, ECF No. 34, is 
DENIED. 
SO ORDERED.   
Date:  March 26, 2025

BERYL A. HOWELL 
United States District Judge
